['you repeat the same action expecting something different something new something fresh and after repeated tries what you finally create or destroy is something entirely different but remarkably similar at the same time a creation of something new from ages past a relic to be used once more epitomizes such qualities in a manner that takes what their predecessor had previously done and made some in my eyes welcoming changes it should also be noted since the game is different from the first some things remain the same and since the game draws heavily from time traveling expect lots of questions and eyebrow raising as well no more will players be restricted to one path throughout the game like the previous areas are more fleshed out with quests involving a lot of back tracking in order to complete them in order to earn cp crystogen points which is used to upgrade your characters in the crystarium players who played the previous installment will remember this as their go to way to leveling up their character usually by battling to accrue cp or exp or doing side quests to earn more cp and unlock fragments and oh boy fragments and artifacts you will hear this in the story a lot being heard basically in it s most basic form their a plot device that you need to progress through the story using the items above one can traverse through time in different eras called af after the fall from don t be alarmed though the game doesn t make it like after etc you will only visit relative and important eras spanning different areas to explore an interesting twist with time travel is the addition of paradoxes and alternate timelines which the game heavily abuses to see different areas dramatically change in setting and thus irrevocably change the power to reverse such paradoxes is up to you mainly but i found the different eras in different places pleasing and a welcome change exploration has been revamped coinciding with side quests so expect a lot of backtracking to either farm for cp materials and even a chance of taming a creature whereas before you can only go forward in the story for the first game here you can keep going back and restart eras to replay the events prior to see it all again hell there s even a casino area and chocobo racing which i felt was rigged against me or i just suck badly a new mechanic reminiscent of capturing pok mon or digimon upon battles you have a chance to tame the creature you are facing these creatures range from smallest to large creatures you primarily face in the ffxiii universe of course each creature you tame can also be infused and made stronger using another creature to boost their capabilities if their compatible enhancing their role adding new abilities or even adding resistances they can also be leveled up using items compatible for them different from cp using items like potent chip potent slivers etc these items can be bought from shops or earned as drops from battles to enhance your creature quickly eliminating the need to grind them each item is different and can be used to upgrade their hp only their magic only or both some creatures are unique and can be tamed enabling strong party members while others you can t tame like bosses for instance or some creatures like c eith the battle system remains the same with paradigms and roles commando ravager sentinel medic saboteur and synergist however with the new creature mechanic you can expect a lot of new experimentation to create your own team that suits you coupled with the creature taming it provides a diverse and fun way to hunt for new companions to suit your battles and become stronger fan of the old will immediately be familiar with the same battle mechanic with the same o l atb rate but this time you can unlock your roles via crystarium and unlock more atb charges and boost your roles upon completing a round in the crystarium it pleasant needing no introduction to the battle system with several new additions to the system with taming story wise with time travel usually gives me headaches to understand the convoluted sense of the story but in this game they don t make it overtly complicated raising the right questions that will sooner or later be understood in the progressing story what really changes the story up are the dialogue options during events only four choices to depend on what you will say and these events will pop up again and again to inform the player of important events i m guessing it all lodges back into paradox endings you can achieve quick time events are included with this sequel in order to gauge player choice usually within a cinematic event you are prompted with qte to progress through the story completing them rewards items while not completing them makes you restart the whole progress and while it can be annoying to wait for the button prompts the events were short and not so much that it was intrusive and bothersome some qte are unique in providing a choice of a certain different path to take than a usual previous route you play as serah the sister to lightning from the previous game in a race against time really to solve paradoxes with the adorable mog which you can torture by throwing to various places to pick up items and reveal hidden items in the world but wait there s more a future guy also travelled back in time to help you because you need a partner his name is noel and you in essence share the leader role with him meaning you can switch from running around the world as noel or serah or face battles as noel or serah while it sucks i can t change them to be just creature parties i found the cast to be likable and sympathetic to their cause to save time and reach lightning in valhalla in true final fantasy fashion you can even customize your creatures and outfit serah and noel in different attire moogle too and guess what even your creatures can have certain adornments on them you find in the game or buy music and battle themes some may remember some old sound tracks which fit the times you are exploring providing a soothing comfort and others new provide the tension to keep your body tense reading to spring into action to compare versus its predecessor is like comparing a baby to a child the changes in the game make it very diverse from exploration and taming battling and side quests and dialogue options and more it takes the criticisms of the first installment and in my opinion improves it to make it better for the player to enjoy while it may seem drastic to add many new mechanics and along with a new protagonist represents a bold risk that ultimately paid off total times beaten is based off how much i enjoyed the game date reviewed posted edited in paragraph note i finished on my i got through a certain point in my pc copy where my computer would just be downright unplayable in battles making my fps fluctuate below to below but exploring was fine just battling also my copy did not contain any dlc ']

['while final fantasy xiii could be described as a piece of stringy meat that s though to chew but still occasionally tasty final fantasy is the whole burger with some ingredients you may or may not like this game is almost universally better than the first game in the trilogy combat is a bit faster and more streamlined with an additional pokemon like system that lets you use monsters during battle exploration is less linear you can jump at any time there s many different areas and everything is a bit more open the soundtrack is fantastic as usual and the story is about as much of a hit or miss as in xiii though i personally love all of the characters and stories in this trilogy the only fault of this game as it were is that it is part of a trilogy that debuted with a very mixed game final fantasy xiii was linear repetitive and restrictive until the hour mark but it had a setting story and characters many people loved as well as a rather unique battle system still not many people wanted to play through the long initial linear gameplay loop and thus xiii got the reputation it at least slightly deserved it pays off to have played it though as many events and characters are recurring in it also is nice to see the evolution the trilogy makes from first to second game how every complaint is either solved or alleviated sure it isn t perfect the port in particular is very flawed when it comes to frame rate and performance and the male main character is slightly irritating but it is leaps and bounds better compared to xiii which was a true flawed gem though more flawed than gem as someone who loves the trilogy it s a great fun upgrade with returning characters familiar and new locations newfound freedom in environments and movement and an addicting gameplay loop of improving main characters noel and serah through the now better crystarium and collecting fragments as you jump through time and space to fix past and future if you didn t like xiii this might remedy the trilogy for you but you should ve at least played part of the first game first personal rating ']

['i ll start this review with the obvious that i am sure most reading will have seen time and time again yes the graphical capabilities of this game on the pc are untrue it runs slower than sometimes dropping quite low in more intense battles larger view battles this is nota fault of anyone s pc but how the game was programmed with the in mind a poor architecture it does not make use of the full capabilities of gpus or multi core cpus therefore it will run similarly on older computers as it might on a state of the art the software is the limit not the hardware that said i do have an older pc i played in a window at that resolution using the smallest shadow map and mpaa it ran alright for the most part as i said it had it s slow moments but was hardly unplayable as some might have suggested i do play modern games at post but do not find low fps to be a kill all i could probably have upped the shadow and aa and still been fine no crashes no critical flaws to the game in that regard i could have been lucky but that was my experience now then on to the game review itself would i recommend this game yes the story i find rather touching if a little too sappy at times i don t find it really killed the story of the first but rather fleshes it out the combat remains quite close to final fantasy which is a plus albiet there are times when i felt it was overly easy comparatively explained later the time traveling and gate closing mechanics give you chances to go back and redo areas to complete them differently where available unlike final fantasy you do not need to replay the game through from the start multiple times to see everything you will need to replay sections but so far nothing i have seen too much repeating the world is definitely more open than it was in the first game there is more to explore than narrow hallways still very closed in spaces comapred to world maps in the older games but better now for the things i did not care for ease of battles battling in seemed a bit more tactical than it is in i attribute this to the libra spell which you could cast at will in the first game in this game there are librascopes you can find or buy for exorbitant prices about mid game but no actual simple libra spell to get data on monsters initially this means the game can t be too harsh for not paying complete attention to the monsters while you fight them without foreknowledge of the enemies you just have to constantly hit them until information is revealed often through multiple encounters if you don t avoid fighting a long way through the game most your random battles until the very end will revolve around three commandos just nuking everything with blitz and ruinga auto battle will be used overall as very rarely do you need to worry about selecting proper skills not to say that there are no times it s better to manually control especially if less than ideally leveled but mostly that revolved around me applying proper debuffs to certain enemies in that regard though i felt a lot of the battles could just be brute forced compared to with only a few that it really mattered to focus on it all many times if you didn t care about time too much having a strong sentinal member not too hard to get early on and upgrade later could really ease it speaking of character classes the wheel as it were of your party member rather than a single character with multiple classes you capture and raise various monsters for the roles each monster only has a single role and you can only have equipped monsters at a time to fill various roles for the most part this isn t a big deal raising them isn t too specifric unless you need uber monsters to help the uber enemies situation even then i don t see the value in perfectly upgraded partners and speaking up upgrades the crysterium is very lack luster to me compared to the first game i liked how you could choose which class to level in what order in the first game but each character would ultimately max out at a certain stat level when all was finished in the first game you had a max level for a given area which forced more strategy on the player as they could no brute force it as much this game regular battles are basically infinite cp batteries you will be maxed well before the end of the game unless you really rush how you level though is is a single crysterium for all classes on each character depending which class you level though at different points in the crysterium including even odd levels on some classes gives different bonus stats in short there is an ideal way of leveling each character while others could leave you with somewhat less than great stats depending which all you leveled nothing game breaking but if you are a perfectionist prepare to study and research ideal leveling order lastly a few of the fragments in the game are a real time sink and pain to get grinding certain enemies to get a lot of gil to just dump at one point taping a button on the controller down on the slot machines just to make sure i win a certain amount over a few hourts while i browsed the web battling every enemy at least once including rare enemies and some that have a chance of not spawning at all on a run through an area before you have to reset the area and try again making sure to explore every last detail of every map for completion just tedium work really that aside i do not regret this purchase it fixes some of the problems i had with but introduces different naggings despite my naggins though i felt compelled to play it through and enjoyed the ride a few points that were dull busy work but overall a fun game just be prepared to look to the next game if you want any sort of conclusion because this one literally pulls a halo with a to be continued ']

['in comparison to we are given a ton more free roam this time the images on missions typically tell you where to go and for the story you just need to pay attention except about mid game you have to go through wild artefact portals till you find the right one which if you are unlucky will be the very last one and make you go find more wild artefacts first another massive change is instead of having a large party you play as either serah or noel and also have animal companion which has its own rule can be upgraded etc most encounters in the game can be turned into an assistant character for your slot the story concept focuses on time travel and rifts so it can get very confusing but also a change to the typical final fantasy the theme is what i would call despair so it is more sad oriented rather than a happy fantasy and this concept is used throughout the whole story you have the option to revert all progress in that map which is useful so you can never really mess up and only need to do a single play through revert time to accomplish everything the battle system is the same as just a more polished ui and for the most part the game is easier and requires less grinding and there are less gaps in stats between you and the enemy there are not many choices for equipment this time as the weapons you get are very linear and you just buy these from the store the other equipabbles are accessories which each have a consumption value and you have a maximum value that you can fill up with accessories there is no upgrading this time so if any aspect of this game is linear it would be the items you get the music is what is truely amazing throughout the whole game and what really makes it enjoyable there is an easy option so if you want to experience the soundtrack and just play the story that would be a possibility the puzzles well the clock one can be really annoying and gets very tedious there is a site on google that you can put in the values and get the solution if these gets frustrating or tedious the platform and connect the dots are more enjoyable there are technical issues encountered one is the regular fps drops which is mostly during free roam so it doesn t ruin anything cutscenes and battles never were affected for me the other issue is rather annoying and that is this strange super load static buzz when opening the game a trip to google will give you the info on setting a certain file to admin which eliminated the noise overall it was fun for a playthrough the music was the highlight of it all the combat entertaining story decent enough playing as serah in her swimsuit was fun too noel can go away though he reminds me of sora from kingdom hearts with the voice of tidus from caius was cool personal experience score can be confusing because it is based on time travelling between rifts but it was something different and better than a lot more despair in this one though which is why it intrigues me sound the soundtrack shines pretty quickly with some epic and intense music that rivals primal fights graphics great improvement from version however it has quite a few fps drops while free roaming controls pretty much what you know from switching between roles for those large attacks can be annoying when you have to move fast and scroll through the list game length hours of content about if you do a large portion of the adventuring and collecting a bit more if you want to get max gear and do the super bosses in the colliseum ']

['playing this game right after finishing a completionist run of ffxiii it s really apparent just how much they changed for the better compared to the original the story pacing is much better and the plot isn t nearly as convoluted as the first game your party is no longer a revolving door of people side quests are varied and include more story rather than just being kill quests and the endgame postgame has a whole host of objectives rather than just farming turtles for hours on end for gil and cp i wasn t sure how i would feel about monster capturing being introduced into the game but they re well incorporated into the gameplay you can do as much or as little as you want to finish the story and even for the end postgame objectives there s a bunch of monsters aimed at mid endgame growth that require less resources to level but can easily help you conquer all end postgame tasks for the achievements and for those who really love monster capturing raising there s a fairly in depth system for raising and tweaking your monsters to build them out just the way you want the devs also did a great job in adding fragment skills which are accessible as your collect more fragments and progress the game these include increasing or decreasing the encounter rate increasing cp gain and increasing monster capture chances among other perks having a system in the game to tweak playstyle preferences as a reward for completing side objectives in the game is a really great idea and something i think other jrpgs should implement more often my one and only gripe with the game is the optimization there is a great guide here on steam that provides solutions to fix or mitigate issues the game has but it s a shame that fan made patches are required at all to make the game function as it should a problem that cropped up somewhat frequently was reduced frame rate it was never unbearable but it wasn t pleasant thankfully this only occurred in the most populated of areas even though i have a pc that s years old at this point during my roughly hours of playtime i only had the game hard crash on me once after applying the fan made patches which i think is a pretty good shout out to the effectiveness of the fan made solutions all in all it s a shame that not many people played this game due to the reputation that the first game garnered from fans but for anyone that enjoyed or didn t mind the shortcomings of the first game or is even just interested in revisiting these games was a very enjoyable journey from beginning to end and in my opinion worth checking out ']

['certified banger takes everything good about the first game and runs with it no more going through whole chapters before unlocking the game s primary mechanics instead you ll find everything you need within the first hour and the rest of the game is spent trying to use and abuse those mechanics to get to the end one new one that i loved is the monster pack system which gives you a chance to recruit enemies to your party they do a great job of making your party feel more personalized throughout which is nice it also helps that the story feels a lot more immediate than the first game with a more compelling villain than the one from the first game that gives the final boss gauntlet a lot more oomph on top of that the soundtrack is a banger full of poppy vocal tracks that make exploring feel all the more breezy oh yeah this game has exploring too i love but going from its hallways to this game s open levels is going to make it hard to ever touch again my only qualms are that the visuals seem like they ve taken a hit in some places and that the combat feels less responsive if you queued up all your abilities in lightning would go as soon as her atb filled in serah and noel feel like they sometimes delay their actions for up to a couple seconds after their atb fills which feels less punishing here because combat seems a bit slower but it s still not good it also makes the classic atb refresh strategy way less effective which sucks because that always felt good to do well in the first game oh and the clock puzzles suck if you re having trouble with them just search for a clock puzzle solver that s what i did all in all it s a great game and has already cemented itself as one of my favorite in the franchise ']

['after the atrocious first entry in the xiii series i layed my hands upon and oh boy i was surprised unlike its predecessor this feels like a jrpg you can travel freely and are not restricted to a one way street anymore you get cities with npcs roaming around the battle system is not much deeper but with the new monster system they added a cool feature unfortunately next to one active monster you only get two characters serah and noel serah is sweet and lovely just like in the first game but noel is your standard cookie cutter jrpg hero with some neat details here and there but one of the most important additions to the xiii series the battle doesn t end when your active characters die this time around it swaps to your other character and only if that one dies as well it is game over so you have some time to resurrect your fallen party member too bad there are some mega attacks again that insta kills your whole squad when you re lower than hp but as far as i can say this is only in the last boss battle also the grinding is less noticeable here because you have to backtrack every now and then the problem is that at one point in the story you have to have enough keys to open portals to what i thought at first optional areas looks like some of them contain very important objects and since you never know to what area a new portal will lead you to have to get lucky or own all those precious keys and they are well hidden at times all around the world are translucent objects and containers you can reveal with your moogle and oh boy they are hard to spot sometimes unfortunately most of the side quests rely on this mechanic so i hope you have good eyes but at least it got neat side quests i look at you ffxiii archylte steppe once again all levels look great with different looks and feel they get rehashed but it s okay considering the plot and yes story although it is muuuch better than final fantasy xiii s mess of fal cie l cie and more it is still a tad convoluted but because the story is sprinkled nicely in between the chapters and different areas i pretty much enjoyed it the whole game just feels more complete and well thought out somehow the battles feel more fun although they are practically random encounters and the music is also fantastic again a tad too much singing though but most of the time it fits is in fact a huge step up from the first game but not a perfect final fantasy game if you want to catch up on the franchise i would recommend skipping ffxiii ']

['this sequel offers improvements over everything from the past game gameplay wise there s much more side content and less tedious and not grindy at all compared to xiii there are npcs to talk to even difficulty spike only toward the final chapter of the game hinting at collecting more fragments which essentially are what you get through side content getting all of them is required to the game and learn the most about it not all dlcs from the console version are included but they are good and the modding community was able to restore those not included on the narrative side of things this game introduces the two most important characters of the trilogy caius and yeul together with noel who are very well characterised and likeable characters the characterization of serah the main protagonist alongside noel is not too good or deep the game also presents alternate endings as side content though they re not too important with the exception of the secret cutscene you get by unlocking and before meant to be read after playing final fantasy xiii before and final fantasy fragments after meant to be read after completing i found the narrative relevance of this two novels high and great compared to the novel of xiii graphics are good but heavily damaged compared to the original console release with several bugs some of which the modding community managed to fix soundtrack is great ['final fantasy xiii part game picks up right after the first one however this time you don t play as lightning but her younger sister serah after the events of the first game lightning is missing and everyone except for serah seems to have forgotten all about her one day when a meteor falls from the sky serah encounters noel a man from the future who says he has brought a message to her from lightning along with the cute creature mog they set out on a mission to find lightning and stop whoever is messing up the timeline travelling to the past the future and even alternate timelines in order to do so the fighting is similar to the first game both characters can be assigned any one of six different roles which can be used to form various paradigms formations and you can freely jump from one paradigm to another as many times as you like during combat unlike the first game however this time you only have two controllable characters the third party slot is filled by any wild monster that you managed to capture after defeating it each monster has one specific role can be upgraded by using materials and can even gain new abilities by absorbing other monsters while i personally preferred just having three playable characters in the party the new monster system is decent as well once you get the hang of it other than that the two games are fairly similar however here are a couple of other differences in the first game when your party leader died you would lose now as long as one of the two main characters stay alive the fight goes on puzzles there are plenty of puzzles throughout the second game there are three puzzle types in total each ranging from easy to hard difficulty some of the puzzles can be a bit challenging but they never get hard and i thought they were a nice bonus you also have a couple of mini games mixed in like chocobo racing and slot machines weapons and accessories are much more basic this time and there is no need to run around farming materials in order to upgrade them you need materials to upgrade your monsters but it s far from as grindy as the material gathering in the first game now for my main complaint about this game it is sooo poorly optimized saving to the steam cloud will usually crash the game so you have to turn of the steam cloud and save locally taking screenshots might crash the game which sucks since the game looks gorgeous minimizing the game might crash the game even just walking through a door crashed my game once in addition to the crashing the resolution settings are broken in order to get the game to look good on my monitor i had to set the resolution to preferably however by doing this the game would not let me take any screenshots and minimizing the game would cause it to crash even more frequently i could make some other complaints like the inclusion of wild artefacts which are keys used to open time gates the problem with that is that they are located in the most random places across several different zones and oh yes they are also transparent if i hadn t looked it up online i would never have been able to find them all still since i enjoyed the game a lot and my only main complaint is that it s a very poor port i definitely recommend final fantasy just remember to play the first one first and know that you will probably have to play the third one to know how the story really ends and since some people might get fooled by the picture at the top of the page you do not get to play as lightning in this game unless you play the dlc if those terms are acceptable then no need to hesitate any longer just buy the game ']

['as you might recall final fantasy xiii was pretty much reviled everywhere as a response square enix released a sequel that promised to fix everything that was wrong with the previous game did it work yeah sorta the first thing that is immediately apparent with the game is that there is no longer any linearity in fact the game is the opposite of xiii with both the story and game systems taking a free form approach allowing you to level your characters the way you want and tackle the story chapters with quite a bit of degree of freedom though this freedom also means there s some tedious back forth in some sections speaking of story it s still nonsensical with a lot of reading done through datalogs to get the gist of it like xiii was liked it more than xiii but that s mostly due to being a sucker for sci fy plots like time travel and for graphically the game s a bit worse than xiii but nothing serious that could distract you some places look just as great as xiii did academia looks pretty gorgeous graphical settings are a exact carbon copy from xiii with nothing to set both of em apart in that regard patch for xiii released at the same time as this released the performance did change though for the worse this game runs even worse than xiii did on the exact same hardware i usually don t mention audio but final fantasy games in general are known to have good soundtracks and xiii are no exceptions special mention goes to that ridiculous chocobo metal song it s just too silly to not like it so the tl dnr improved sequel marred yet again by performance issues buy it if you re a fan or is on sale ps same regional restrictions that applied to xiii applies here asian version is restricted to the asian region get the western version if you want an unrestricted version source ']

fixed this pc port of final fantasy doesn t give you the same freedom let s talk about the port first why is it bad a lot of the game s visuals are a little subpar comapred to its console counterpart but what really gets to me right now in my first minutes in the game is the quality of the audio the audio for everything except the soundtrack is all muffled and in poor quality a complete downright shame which can really really ruin the game for some the soundtrack in is just fine though no issues there but i would suggest avoid playing with a headset as hearing how muffled and poor some of the voices were done might just put you off now on to the game itself when ffxiii was released a major complaint was that it was mainly all hallways and corridors all the way up to chapter when you reached an open world area and where you would spend most of your time playing the game ultimately in this issue is fixed much to the delight of those giving the xiii series another chance straight away in the starting area of the game you ll get the chance to explore all the nooks and crannies of the town really giving away the sense of exploration and detail in each individual map the game is potential set the option to default to abilties and give yourself a challenge in this game the paradigm system is one of my favourite battle systems in the final fantasy franchise for a reason give ['i am going to be straight to the point i think the game isn t bad nor is it good it s definitely not a good sequel but there are ways to enjoy it depending on what you re looking for i personally think the ending of ff xiii felt complete and mildly satisfying so while there were possible directions a sequel could ve explored that could ve been interesting this is simply not it generally speaking the gameplay is very similar with a few quality of life improvements however the story took a nosedive by introducing time travel and while i generally enjoy the idea when it s done right in this game it s not i would even say it s a mess for the plot to be able to enjoy the game it s better to turn off your brain and don t try to make sense of what the game pulls out of nowhere or simply ignore as much of the story as possible and have fun with the gameplay i certainly couldn t because i play final fantasy games for a good story primarily these days and while the pacing issues from the first game are somewhat alleviated the writing took a significant hit in quality it s also important to understand that by playing this sequel you will have to play lightning returns afterwards to get an actual ending since this one is a cliffhanger the other notable issue is the quality of this port that practically requires you to patch it manually thanks to the community dedicated enough to fix the mess square enix left on steam with bad performance and occasional crashes back to the gameplay combat is pretty much the same but now you re stuck with only characters and back to the monster party member of ff but less interesting not like it was interesting to begin with to fill up the empty space in the group character progression is not gated by story progression but it s even more streamlined than before and weapons accessories can t be upgraded like in the previous game but there are some crafting in the shop that needs specific ingredients to purchase some occasional pieces of equipment about the linearity the areas are more varied and open and the time travel mechanic that give a level select basically a bunch of locations at different years so with multiple paths you get a bunch of endings which are mostly bad endings but fun i guess to see different outcomes even if the actual ending is obviously the same for everyone the thing is how time travel is made in this game is kind of boring after a while you get there you have to solve a time paradox distorting the world spawning monsters and whatnot but even if the situations are slightly different from one place to another it gets repetitive eventually the most notable positive change outside of linearity and some side content would be how they finally realised an animation for switching paradigm was a bad idea and now it s instant so you don t get randomly hit by the enemy sometimes i am struggling to find good things to say because there are not many without repeating some of the goods of the previous ['the answer for this game is a very tentative maybe but erring on the side of not recommended we ll pass over poor porting outright as a fair amount of that can be mitigated with community fixes you can see the time i ve played and i ve done so without a crash having said that be sure you follow the community guides to fix everything before attempting to play the game as for the game itself interesting lore utterly buried behind loading screens corridor areas endless fetch quests and hidden easter egg hunts i see the things they were trying to improve upon from its predecessor but they failed in pretty much every respect they could have allowed for an engaging exploration of the twin worlds of pulse and cocoon an investigation into their genesis symbiosis and ultimate destiny instead we got magic time gates with a complete disconnect of past present and future it s how you might have expect chrono trigger to work out if the person who wrote it was under the influence of crack cocaine a myriad assortment of what ifs and contradictions with essentially no relevance so far as the overall plot is concerned the sheer amount of asset recycling is staggering the budget for this game was obviously quite low everybody looks the same perhaps forgivable in the and bit era but certainly not beyond very little of the music fits what is being conveyed on screen in the slightest with a few notable exceptions many of the boss fights feel panicky and rushed most of them also require meta knowledge to be successful at the controls are alright but the jumping concept seems a bit tacked on in many places you can hop up a sheer cliff wall but if the story demands it a piece of concrete that a child could hop over bars your further progress one or two inconsistencies like this could be looked over but this game does this over and over and over again it becomes grating after a while my biggest issue personally though is how disjointed the world seems after all this time i still have no idea what the geographical layout of either of these worlds looks like it s just a magical hop from cave to cave without any real sense of where anything is located relative to anything else this was a serious problem in the original game and was actually made worse in the sequel hard as that may be to believe if fetch quests and collecting are your thing this game is for you if you like hunting for lore in blobs of text this game is for you if you re somewhat of a masochist or otherwise exceptionally bored this game is for you other than that your money is almost certainly better spent elsewhere read taco bell if you had to pinpoint the exact spot of terminal decline for the final fantasy series this trilogy is probably it ']

['is only the third direct sequel in the long running franchise after and but considering how beloved and were and how was it s also the only direct sequel in the franchise that really had to improve upon what came before and despite a short development time of only actually managed to partially fix what many disliked about its predecessor miraculously first of doesn t fix what isn t broken the great atb battle system from makes a return which means that stagger bars paradigm shifts and the crystarium are back again there have been some adjustments however as drew criticism for only opening up its battle system late into the game now most jobs are available from the beginning and as core abilities are unlocked quickly character development and stats can be influenced by the player from the start another change concerns the party system as only features two protagonists there s a third character slot that needs to be filled during battle this can be done by taming certain enemies after fighting them in the wild this might sound like but in praxis it s even more simple than that a monster only one per species might join your party after battle which is simply based on chance and while monsters can be levelled by infusing them with certain items their job as well as their passive active abilities are predetermined only their stats as well as their looks can be slightly influenced by the player but even if the monster system is somewhat simple it allows for easy and quick party customization want your protagonists to focus on certain jobs in the beginning simply swap in a fitting monster for the jobs you might only want to level later all monsters also got special empathy abilities which can be triggered after a certain time which can range from attack with decent manage to very useful party wide heals the only downside to the monster system might be the additional time investments to gather the right materials in order to fully boost them to their max level another common complaint about concerns linearity as there were many straight corridors and very few open areas to explore this has also been addressed by which consists of many open areas although most of them are on the smaller side think though the similarities don t end there in both games areas can only be accessed by selecting them from a map in a central hub which means the world doesn t feel as connected coherent as the ones in or for example also offers less interesting locations compared to but is about the same visual quality otherwise which is hardly surprising since many assets are reused the soundtrack is quite varied this time around which might fit the difference of the individual locations but doesn t really seem coherent in the bigger picture additionally there are a few moments where the music choice feels ill fitting which is extremely rare for a title as with the pc port of is of very poor quality again this does include console exclusive dlc this time around visit for fan made fixes if you really want to play this game one day the focus of the remaining review concerns the central theme of time travelling in terms of gameplay it s mainly used to restrict the available locations want to access a certain timeline for the next story segments find the right items artifacts to do so want to gather all available collectibles fragments manipulate the time of certain locations via artifacts though a time travel element during battles exploration would ve been interesting time travel is only used to alter entire locations e g visit the same place years in the future the real problem of introducing time travel and the main problem of as a whole is the influence time travelling has on the story time travel stories are very hard to pull off and can quickly turn into a narrative mess as the audience needs to be properly guided through a labyrinth of similar but different timelines since time travel could potentially change about every action character or location in the story it s very important to make sure that the audience can follow what you re trying to tell them needless to say that doesn t manage to do that already struggled with its mythos and storytelling adding time travelling to the mix would certainly not help to clear things up for one thing while does requires lore knowledge of its predecessor it also feels strangely disconnected as it s focusing on entirely different aspects and foes of the world while the cast of the original game returns in very limited capacity expect for previous protagonist lightning the story mostly focuses on the sister of lightning serah as well as the last human of future earth noel thanks to elements that weren t even hinted at during the previous game serah and noel need to time travel in order to achieve a certain proper timeline while going against a new one dimensional and uninteresting villain the resulting story is simply a mess which is not very surprising but not exactly what i hoped for either serah and noel are a step up from the protagonists of but they re not going to leave a lasting impression either and considering there are only very few characters present in the story that s saying something it s also quite easy to get lost in what happens in which timeline and why especially if you re taking longer breaks between game sessions the basic story might be downright predictable but it s the poorly explained surrounding elements including the time travelling itself that can cause confusion some side stories with important information once sold as dlc on console are also only unlocked once the story has been completed it also has to be mentioned that once again many important lore bits are hidden in datalog text entries they re even worse to unlock this time around however as you re required to find the corresponding fragments hidden in the game world if you want to read them there are of them all of which are required for the secret ending finally it doesn t help that the uneven story of ends on an unsatisfying cliffhanger and a literal to be continued screen even as the middle part of a trilogy this cliffhanger comes off so abruptly forced it really makes you wonder why you even bothered playing through the story of to begin with it s gameplay might be fine but the messy story turns into a game that s only for really devoted fans of who still want more ']

['it s time i can t say i expected much after the dissapointment that was final fantasy xiii but i ended up enjoying this game a lot more than the original if you want to read my review for the original xiii time for pros and cons the game is no longer a long corridor the areas are open with things to be discovered and time travel gives a good excuse to see many diverse and interesting locations there is a nice amount of different locations and some areas are the same location but in a different time period good music overall and some tracks are superb like these the narrative is very focused compared to the muddled mess in the original this is mostly thanks to there only being a handful of main characters the villian is great you completely understand why he is doing the things he does the combat is a lot better this time around while still feeling like the same system when you changed your partys roles in the orignal game there was a animation that took you out of the battle for about seconds this might not seem like a big deal but removing this animation and just letting the battle flow like it was before does a lot to improve the pacing of fights in this game if the character you are controlling dies you just take control of the other person in your party this was lacking in the original game and it is very nice to see them address this problem you can also change what character you are controlling mid battle a very welcome addition the leveling system is actually very open to customization compared to the linear mess in the original if you want to you could go through the entire game without ever getting the ability to heal not that i would reccomend it but it s awesome that you can do that you have characters that are stuck in your party and a third slot open for a monster that you have tamed you can tame most of the monsters in the game and every monster has its own abilites and base stats i say base stats because you could have behemoth monsters but level them up completely differently you can also find a lot of cosmetic items for the monsters including hats each monster also has a unique limit break ability there is loads of optional content through the story you will be collecting fragments to unlock new locations and time periods you get these items by doing side quests and just finding them in chests when i finished the game i only had out of so if you want to you could spend a lot of time with this game this time around they included some actual graphics options including resolution msaa up to and shadow resolution the game can run at fps but there is dual audio i played it in english and everyone was fine except for lightning she has less peronality than microsoft sam good thing lightning only has about minutes of screentime in the entire game weapon system is better than in the original in the original you could upgrade your weapons meaning that if you just kept upgrading your original weapon you had no reason to ever buy a new one and because of the effort and gil needed to upgrade a single weapon you literally had no reason to ever get a new weapon in this one you get access to new weapons in the shop the further you progress in the game some are just a straight up upgrade stat wise anyway but other weapons have special abilites stuck to them but these require some additional items aswell as gil to be bought all in all it s a straightforward system but at least it works unlike the original game leads nicely into travel elements are very it s magic i ain t got to explain but then the characters waste a lot of time in cutscenes talking about how it works and it just ends up wasting time the combat is still very much a case of just switching your classes to match the situation and pressing the auto button there was only one time in the game where i actually selected commands and that was because i was against an enemy that had health regen but my character refused to cast poison with auto you can t control your characters in battles this can be really annoying in a lot of different sittuations like when you have somebody as a tank with the ability to divert enemy attention to themselves and the party just stands around really close to each other as a result everyone gets hit regardless this defeats the entire purpose of a system that works in a space story was okay at best but a lot of time was wasted on nonsensical time travel and in the end it just came down to x thing is a paradox we must kill fix it x often being just a random boss enemy in the area the story was more interesting when it focused on the stories of ciaus yuel serah and noel the game has very unstable framerate i never dropped under though nonetheless it can be very annoying to watch as the framerate jumps all over the place the game crashed at least once every hours the biggest time lost as a result was hour regardless this was very annoying and by doing a short google search i can see that i am not the only one with this issue this time around there are minigames something lacking from the original but all of them are luck based and some are even locked behind dlc i must admit i wasn t excpecting much out of this game but all the non linearity and freedom came as a big surprise with loads of optional content much improved combat system and non linearity in almost every aspect this game is actually worth playing unlike the original as long as you are fine with a combat system that is very simplistic and a story that makes little to no sense i will likely edit this review soon if i forgot to talk about something ']

['got the changes that people wanted from ffxiii less linear you can actually spec your characters while leveling them up change leaders in the middle of a fight which means you no longer lose the fight if the leader dies enemies randomly appear rather than already being there premptive strikes are a lot easier and make more sense introduced paradigm save slotsthe only major downside was the total nerf of the synergist role and how you applied buffs haste is no longer a castable spell but rather a bonus for getting a premptive strike some items also apply it they also added aoe buffs which i guess balances it out the two main characters do not have any offensive buffs you can only get them from your monsters or their feral links removed fortisols accessories are restricted each one has a numeral cost some of the accessories got absolutely dirt nerfed overal i like just as much as the first it feels more fast paced in both the story and the gameplay the only thing you might have some problems with are finding some good monsters to level up in your party especially early some time and playing through the game again for the third time there are some issues i noticed the game is very stat orientated compared to the first what i mean by this is that in the first game your stats were generally limited by the crystarium in though there is no limiting while this can be seen as a good thing in some ways for it creates a situation where if you grind too much the game play becomes very bland the game play is what i loved in the fights and paradigm creating and executing alternatively if you don t know what you re doing and rush the story everything will seem overpowered and you ll be forced to do side quests and grind which isn t the worst thing but can be frustrating this last play through i did i tried to be optimal in leveling accessories and getting the monsters i wanted and i quickly became overpowered without doing many side quests or grinding the game play at that point was just sit in relentless assault until the enemy is dead no paradigm changes needed the only fights to look forward to were bosses and late game enemies which were way to strong for me at the time but serve as late game content a lot of people love the monster system but its one of the things i don t like the most about this game as i mention in the original review you have to have a syn monster because the two main characters don t have offensive buffs if you want to be optimal and have max damage output you ll also need a com monster to make the cerebus paradigm following that you would need a rav monster to raise the stagger gauge as fast as possible with triple rav so realistically your third character in this game only has three different roles and if you want to be optimal you really have no choice in the matter com rav and syn the two main characters can cover all roles outside those three just fine on their own sen its more a temporary damage reduction for everyone and you dont even need to level it sab both main characters can cover all abilities in the role and swapping between leaders means you can get what ever debuff you need when you need it med finding a monster that has all the med abilities you need and has a large health pool and magic stat is such a huge investment that its not even worth it again the two main characters can cover all the abilities in med a med monster is really only useful at the start of the game when the two main characters dont have access to the med role or dont have levels in the role another gripe i have with the monster system is your third character has variable health in fights since the third character is three different monsters when you switch a monster from half health the monster coming in will have half health as well having a monster with a low max health is too detrimental if a monster with a low max health comes in after another monster switches out after taking a beating there s a good chance that low max health monster is gonna die real quick and early game when you rely on a monster for the med role can be really frustrating since most have really low max life that being said the game is very short and confusing story wise i feel this game was a knee jerk reaction to the initial public thoughts of and that hurt it a lot instead of sticking to its guns and doing its own thing it tried to damage control the game is so non linear that it gets confusing and the story can be contradicting at times depending on what path you go down the game can still be fun but it has some issues that never had ']

['you played ffxiii and want to know if this one is worth playing that depends on what you did and didn t like about xiiii ll compare the two games some to give you an idea of how the sequel changed up the is much more open than the first game each area can be explored and has hidden objects to discover there are also occasionally different enemy types for different parts the zones there are less unique locations than the first game but i think the openness of the areas makes up for it party members there are the first game had characters to choose from and while many parts forced you into specific configurations of party members there were times that you had a choice of how to compose your party only has two human party members and the third slot is for monster party members that you capture and level up sort of like pokemon there is quite a bit of depth to this mechanic but i still would have liked some extra speaking party members combat largely unchanged big improvements are the ability to continue fighting a battle when your party leader dies and the ability to change leader mid battle some of the sab and syn abilities appear to be missing making those roles a bit more simplified those skills may be present in monster party members that i haven t used yet monsters are not sitting out of the world in this game at least for the most part they act more like the random encounters of older jrpgs with the exception that you can still occasionally avoid them after they have spawned by running away i feel like this is a better system because it mostly prevents you from farming a single enemy over and over like the optimal cp grind in the first game which ultimately led to me giving up on its endgame crafting i disliked the crafting system in the previous game largely because it wouldn t tell you which items were required to improve weapons and it had no indicator to show when a piece of equipment was at it s max level or could be upgrading another rank has solved these problems but also has a much simpler system which lost some of the depth that could have been a vendor sells you new weapons in exchange for crafting materials and occasionally an old weapon too story i found ffxiii s story to be enjoyable but also easily forgettable i didn t think any of the characters were well written or very likable except for maybe saszh and only a few months later i barely remember any of the major plotpoints is much the same case there are parts of the story that i liked but the character dialogue was mostly bland and often grating in particular i found one of the main characters very unlikable and with no option to remove him from my party i had to play the entire game with him endgame i find that i am enjoying end game much more than that of the previous game the path to max level is almost over and i have just been going around doing quests for fragments with barely any true grinding there is a lot to do with the monster party members that i have not done yet that appears like it could get grindy later on i haven t fought any of the hardest bosses in either game yet but for i do think i will end up doing that while i don t know if i can stand the grind in xiii long enough to get there new things puzzles there are some puzzles that are required to be completed in certain areas and for the most part i found these ranged for boring and unenjoyable to frustrating and unenjoyable i think at this point that i ve finished all of the puzzles in the game and i didn t find one of them to be enjoyable at all and i enjoy playing puzzle games occasionally hidden objects there are a lot of hidden objects to find in the game for completion fragments are mostly tied to quests but occasionally hidden throughout the game world there is an indicator to show you how many you are missing in a particular area and i ve been enjoying hunting these down i find them much more interesting than the less varied ci eth stone missions from the first game then there are the wild artefacts which i ended up hating these are hidden objects that must be found to access certain areas most of them i found during regular play but after beating the game i still had a few that i hadn t found and with no indicator hinting at which zone they might be in i had to mindlessly comb every area i had been to looking for the last few i finally did manage to find them all but i found the task very frustrating it feels like the developers might have been assuming that players would just go online for a guide for these but i prefer to avoid outside assistance when possible overall i enjoy it and if you enjoyed the first game you may very well enjoy this one as well it still has many of the flaws that drove away hardcore final fantasy fans but some of those were fixed ']

['first of all do yourself a big favor and turn off cloud save syncing the game will most likely crash often when you try to save unless it s off the game is also locked at unless you download a fan made fix there are definitely slowdowns during gameplay if you use this and voices can come out of sync as a result since lip sync is not directly tied to framerate a horrible mistake imo if you somehow can look past these pretty bad flaws there s a game here that much better than ff xiii with a soundtrack that s both great and laughingly bad this time you re able to tame monsters which is actually great fun there are way more side missions and optional paths this time around and you can even go choboco racing as for the story well it s pretty convoluted to say the least highly simplified one can say that serah lightning s sister in the first game got saved from her crystal stasis at the end of ff xiii however lightning has somehow disappeared serah along with a time travelling dude named noel kreiss agrees to go looking for her and they do that by travelling through time in short it s a mixed bag it has interesting mechanics a story and gameplay that s better that ff xiii but a soundtrack that leaves some things to be desired i m looking at you death metal chocobo song however you can t look away from the horrible load times semi frequent crashes and bad framerate pick this up only if you can cope with the shortcomings some downright unacceptable and puzzling for a pc port taken into account that ff xiii did not have any of these issues do i recommend ff yes do i recommend this port no rating ']

['final fantasy is a hidden gem of the ff series this game is woefully under appreciated by both fans of the ff series and gamers at large if you like chrono trigger you will probably like this game pros story is appropriately grand and enthralling music is amazing and memorable caius ballad is a very cool villain at first i saw him as a discount sephiroth but over time he is fleshed out and made to be his own person neutralcombat system is passably good but nothing special if you played ffxiii you won t really find anything new here some fights do require a bit of strategy read rapid paradigm shifting but mostly you can get through using auto abilities monster collecting shows some promise at first but i ended up using the same monsters through the whole game you will end up using the basket cat as your healer for the majority of the game serah and noel don t do much to stand out as characters cons game pacing is all over the place sequences shift from blindingly rapid narrative advancement to coming to a near standstill performance issues can become frustrating this seems to be hit or miss depending on your specific hardware like many ff games this one takes a while to really get spun up in the beginning the first few hours are a bit of a slog overall i highly recommend this game to any jrpg fan especially those that played and enjoyed ffxiii and or chrono trigger ']

times was also interesting cons reusing some of the music and graphics seemed excessive most of the monsters were common in final fantasy xiii this however did not apply to the world graphics for the most part there are minor performance issues i had the game crash once but it was no big deal for me at some points the game had minor stuttering there are a lot of puzzles in the game some of them ['final fantasy is an adventure game with a lot of cutscenes while the combat is the same as in the previous game most of the fights will be much easier to the point that most of the times i just had to press a a few times with relentless attack being selected as the default paradigm even most of the boss fights were made fairly forgiving that doesn t mean there are not some hard battles but they generally happen in the side content and not in the main gamepath just as in ffxiii you control only the party leader the other two members will act autonomously according to their role this time there is only a cast of main characters serah and noel during most of the game you can set freely who is the party leader so you can have either a female or a male character leading the party around instead of a supporting staff there will be monsters fighting along these two these monsters are captured randomly during fights and can be leveled up with the right type of materials also they can be infused into each other gaining the passive abilities and a level based number of class specific abilities eventually i just used the early peaker types of monsters to get access to high health and infusing the missing skills from other partially leveled monsters the fighting styles are bundled into paradigms where you can set up only up to six to switch between the available paradigms are further limited by the fact that only monster types can be used out of possible role types the only really important monster roles are the sentinel for tanking and ravager for chain bonus building till the midgame a medic was handy but eventually the main cast will level up as makeshift medics too the only other monster that i used was a commando meaning that i skipped on the saboteurs and synergists i leveled up such monsters but because only monsters can be used in a setup i stuck to rav sen med eventually replacing the med with a com leveling the main characters is extremely straightforward you select a role and linearly progress along it the still unlockable skills are listed at the lower right with the level when they unlock by the end of the game i had the main skill at the max level happened around the third of the game and practically all the other roles had all of their available abilities unlocked there is an easy mode in the game but i didn t feel the need to switch to it at any time that meant that the final boss battle lasted well over half an hour since i was defensive enough to survive recover from partial wipes but lacked the offensive power to do high damage in a short amount of time it didn t help that the supporting enemies were continuously resummoned forcing me to kill them again and again as far as i know there is no hard mode the progression through the story is extremely contorted you have to unlock random things on different maps to progress on however there is no guidance whatsoever as to where to go next nodes with still darked out gates or with lot of fragments remaining are a good guess to explore further but you might end at a gate that requires a random fragment that must be unlocked at an unspecified place side quest even when i knew what to search for on the internet finding out the correct route was a matter of lucking out on the search results of all the games that i have played this had the most obtuse online guidance help if you don t follow a full walkthrough guide right from the start and i didn t do that at any point expect a lot of hindrances to progression even the side quests are not highlighted in any way you literally have to talk to everyone hoping to start a side quest instead of getting a random bit of trivia when you do get a side quest there will be a hint image showing the completion location if that image seems entirely unfamiliar it means that it is in a place you haven t traveled yet and of course with no help whatsoever how to get there some maps can be accessed through a special key item the wild artifact as far as i can tell all of those maps are optional you can reach the ending without touching them you get at least one of these artifacts for free on the map i got one as a side quest reward and as a last resort they can be bought for coins in the casino and since money can be freely traded for coins at worst you can buy such a wild artifact for gil don t expect to have the map fully unlocked just by playing through the main game path beside the wild artifact maps there will be some paradox ending maps which i assume can be accessed after finishing the main story line as such having a lot of undiscovered nodes on the map is normal for a simple playthrough through the main storyline most of the times you will encounter enemies through them randomly spawning out of thin air on you in the map i remember only one map with roaming enemies but even there were enemies randomly spawning there is an option of running away from random spawns but that works only if there is enough space to distance yourself from them and they don t have fast units generally there will be no such units also there is a bonus if you can engage an enemy by pressing a instead of being attacked by it or running accidentally into it which is very easy as they spawn out of thin air as you run and in confined spaces its almost guaranteed that you run into them should you fail an encounter after the game over screen you get a retry option starting just before the encounter i didn t know for a long time but the save button can be used to force a retry even before the actual defeat there are a variety of logical puzzles to solve but one kind of them is quite though it is the clock puzzle where the problem is exacerbated by the fact that you don t even know the right starting point and eventually with possible starting points there can be a lot of trials that are doomed from the start i eventually used an online solver you can buy better equipment at the various store points sprinkled througout the game some of them require special components to farm i abstained from selling random junk because i didn t know what would be a useful upgrade component in a hindsight i could have sold everything even the money only weapons should be sufficient just in case you can buy such money only weapons before the final boss fights the graphics of the game were gorgeous but that was partially because i used a texture mod which pushed the graphics to the limits of the engine it already had to keep some texture in the original state to fit into the memory limit the music was good but a lot of it seemed familiar from ffxiii the japanese voice acting was good too as always when there is a choice for native japanese voice acting i used that this time there wasn t text only npcs like in earlier games everything will be spoken out there is manual save in the game and out of combat cut scenes you can save freely as far as i know there is no auto save so always save manually before exiting the game also i used only a single save slot though there might be more the game can be played with keyboard mouse or with a gamepad i naturally used a gamepad the native system intended for the game ironically you can exit the game only with the keyboard either esc enter or as there is no such menu option the game starts with keyboard prompts even if you use a controller be sure to change to controller prompts prior to new game as during the intro part i couldn t figure out how to change that and got keyboard prompts for quick time events even playing with a controller i installed the hd texture mod from nexusmods and which i think is a must for mode the game crashed only once in academia which is the graphically most taxing level with a lot of independent actors ']

['i highly recommend the game but not this port without exaggeration the game crashed more often than i voluntarily shut it down the save system crashes the game and often takes steam with it and even with cloud saves turned off as recommended in several threads reviews i experienced an average of one crash every hour while playing this game three levels actually placed me in an infinite loading screen unless i switched cloud saves back on a risky move since it usually caused a crash and the story requires you to visit two of those levels on multiple occasions this does not appear to be a random glitch since the infinite loading screen happened in every instance of these three levels regardless of era to add insult to injury the two required levels of the three listed glitched out and kept repeating the story events long after they were supposed to be completed there are two boss battles one story and one optional where i had to start the fight with cloud saves turned on but i had to switch to local saves immediately after the fight or else the game would crash if that were not enough the weather machine located in a later level has a chance to crash the game every time it is used story requires it to be used at least three times but side missions require it far more often and i also experienced a small number of crashes for which i could find no cause the trial and error required to find out where i could go and when i could save the game resulted in over hours of lost progress in the game and several more hours were wasted outside of the game rebooting everything there are smaller concerns that can be raised about the lack of sound sliders and the very limited graphics options but those problems don t hold a candle to the constant crashes i will say that while i experienced many softlocks that required reloading levels or rebooting the game the game never glitched in such a way as to make it permanently impossible to complete the objective and that includes ['this is the game should have been it s almost amazing how well square enix managed to improve upon while maintaining it s core principles and mechanics gameplay is an improved version of paradigm atb combat you still have the same roles com rav sab syn med sen and the same maximum of members in your party except now you have the ability to get rare drops from almost everything you fight excluding bosses that allow you to use said monster for your party member this really opens up that much needed flexibility compared to where all party members were essentially the same apart from their full atb skill also important to note is that there s no longer a long animation for paradigm shifting which really feels more natural and doesn t make your characters idle for a few seconds wasting that precious time you could be using to input commands characters feel less clunky and slow in their animations and you get the full combat system available very early on into the story one of the main gripes i had with was that you were forced into the slow progression into unlocking the full capabilities of the paradigm shifting system other than the reasonable improvements it s still essentially combat mechanics you still craft higher tier weapons with monster materials although it s less farmy compared to accessories take a major backseat due to a limitation being placed on the amount of accessories you can hold on one character which different accessories having different amounts of capacity they take up eidolons summons are gone but it s not really missed since you d barely use them in anyway you also get fragment skills which are unlocked as you go along completing the game these have a wide range of effects from changing monster encounter rates to opening up different endings by allowing an alternative path the world itself has been really revamped though you can now jump although you re often blocked with invisible walls in most places and as a result there s a lot more verticality in the map design you aren t forced into a corridor driving you forward towards the story progression is done by visiting areas of varying sizes some small some very large in different time periods you ll often have the option of visiting a place multiple times in different time periods but it s not repetitive due to the slightly altered designs and different npcs still has that gorgeous visual quality from the level design really has an emphasis on creating the perfect atmosphere for the situation it s amazing how well they managed to convey each time period of the same location so uniquely the story s done much better with excellent pacing that feels natural and not forced you unlock new locations and time periods of that said location within a level and progress slowly along with the story although the locations have barely any correlation with each other the story itself is actually done well characters feel natural and likable and the main antagonist is one of the best final fantasy villians in recent memory pacing is done well since you control where and when to go and it s fairly open it feels more like you re just going around places solving time paradoxes and moving onto the next world which is a really nice change from forced pacing there s plenty of optional areas to visit during the story and the hub historia crux allows you to visit past areas instantly without having to retrace your steps sonically this is personally one of my favourites from the recent ff games there s tracks remixed tracks and new music that really helps set the tone of the game there s beautiful orchestral tracks well written vocals and context appropriate background music that help drive the atmosphere of each and every situation although i felt there were a bit too many vocals and it was definite far more than what s usually present in a ff game not that i m complaining though some of the vocal tracks are done perfectly naoshi mizuta outdoes herself in noel s theme which features hauntingly sombre vocals with a simple piano and violin background the song really encompasses the character noel and his struggles and it s used to really emphasise emotional scenes the main battle theme paradigm shift is a fast paced track featuring a vibrant violin a simple but strong drum beat and a bassy synth it really suits the frantic but orderly nature of battles and it s colourful but subdued enough to help focus on the battle eclipse is another standout with vocals acting as a backing to the sharp violins frantic pianos and punchy bassline honestly even if my terrible adjectives haven t convinced you at least listen to the soundtrack it s really good as a pc port it s bad not bad but still pretty bad it has graphical options for resolution anti aliasing and shadow resolutions but nothing else and it s not even ingame but within a window that acts as a launcher of sorts the is still here with it s warning box that s still a popup box outside of the game it s but poorly optimised so you can expect sudden drops in certain areas graphically it s stunning but with few options to tinker around with there hasn t been any bugs i ve noticed though compared to which suffered from random crashes that forced you to save at every available opportunity as pc ports go square enix still has a long way to go all in all it s a good game with great visuals an interesting time travel based story with an optimised combat system from and a very memorable ost better than in every way easily get it if you re a fan of jrpgs it s an excellent choice ']
