['there seems to be a lot of hate for this game stemming from largely unimportant technical issues versus actual game quality so let me give my two cents as an avid gamer with a very diverse array of games and technical knowledge let me start off by saying that this is a console to pc port while this game as all games are have been developed on a pc it was developed originally for an entirely different type of hardware so you can t just take your pc dev source and throw that on a computer and call it a day while there are some technical issues they are largely minor and unnoticeable with a few exceptions i ll cover all of that in detail below gameplay this game uses a similar combat system to its predecessor ffxiii in that rather than micromanaging every move of your team they learn from their combat experience and adjust their fighting on their own you simply tell them what role to fill in the party by changing your party paradigms while this means a whole lot less button pushing and decision making as far as battles go it makes for a more casual gameplay experience and allows battles to be conducted in real time for those of you that still want the final say in what is done how and where to what you can select the abilities individually through the combat menus i don t suggest doing this on boss fights as a note the game is split between exploring maps battling monsters and dialogue as far as the story goes they have a lot of interesting bits there is a solid story to be told and you are fed it through a myriad of time jumps and side quests you could of course straightline the story and be done with the game in a few hours but you d be missing out on a lot of the depth of the story and information take the time to explore the world do the side quests and you will be rewarded for the experience with a rich plot that is severely downplayed in reviews once serah grows a spine and takes up sword and bow for her sister s sake she s a certifiable badass and something new from the previous game you actually have a say in the stories deciding what she says or asks at critical points to affect the information and reactions of the npcs the party mechanics are pretty different now serah and noel are your only real party members and you can swap between which of them leads freely the third party slot is filled by tamed monsters each which has a specific role and can be evolved along the crystarium at the cost of item drops this mechanic is a bit odd but not unwelcomed there s a lot to be said for a behemoth mowing down your enemies along side the mains there are some battles where the characters from the first game assist such as a battle alongside snow fairly early on but i wish there would have been some of that for some of the newer npcs like alyssa who you run into repeatedly and even voices an interest in the party s actions and time travel controls don t use mouse and keyboard sure they work and they will get you through some stuff but they are a bit awkward and clunky the convenience of a controller is that all the controls for the game are easily accessible and don t require reaching across your keyboard and hitting the wrong button during a crucial moment or simply losing track of where your fingers are on the keyboard i am very accustomed to keyboard mouse controls get a controller it will make your life easier and many games benefit from the ease of access of the buttons you need in your hand audio i applaud squeenix for this whole heartedly for those of you who like the english voice cast which they did do an amazing job of casting i might add the game offers the usual english release as seen on the consoles for those of you who prefer to hear the original voices you can choose the original voice track from the japanese version of the game if you know japanese you ll here some inconsistencies between the dialogue and the subtitles that are curious but for the most part both are solid and you won t miss anything one way or the other the music for this game is very easy to listen to though the battle theme is repetitive and a bit obnoxious at times especially as frequently as you end up in battles the rest of the soundtrack during exploration is beautiful and well done rather than simply extending the soundtrack a little from the previous game there are only a few familiar songs from xiii and most of the music for is new nice vocals sung in english for the most part help add to the story as the songs are actually relevant to the plot in their weirdly engrish way i wish the soundtrack was available for this on steam as well graphics here s the bit where things get dicey the game is fantastically beautiful and well worth exploring that said the game s requirements are fairly punishing on most middleweight moderate systems the game runs beautifully on my desktop amd quad core ram crossfired with no measurable issues all those people complaining about frame rates dropping to unplayable levels are either experiencing hardware incompatibility issues or other os related issues such as background processes viruses and malware or everyone s friend system idle process or are simply first worlders with no real concept of what unplayable is and are just whining for attention and because things aren t perfect for them nothing is going to be perfect and this title is no exception to that rule it is playable my laptop struggles a bit more with the game on the other hand but the issues are so minor that i still have no real unplayable moments the game engine is built with an internal frame skipping mechanic that mitigates lower end systems something i don t think many people have noticed while the game may not be running per second it does it s best to keep it as close to as it can i have no complaints with this even when the count drops below this the game is still playing smoothly thanks to the frame skipping with only a little bit of lag during the visually stunning spells like thundaga and ruinga it s running a amd quad core ram and video card in conclusion this game is worth the money at its not like squeenix is trying to milk a new market plus we get most of the dlc at no additional cost the only thing that they could have thrown in to make it a better deal would have been the soundtrack sure the game may occasionally drop in performance a little bit at times but it s never bad enough that the game can t be played and the gameplay experience is not bad i m playing final fantasy on my computer and i m very happy for the experience as a side note i do own both games on consoles so i am aware of how they play there i can t pack up my console and take it on a roadtrip like i can do with my laptop however and as often as i m on the road or in a position that i can t play my consoles this is a nice and welcome option ']

['the first game of the series was perceived as being too linear so squeenix tried to remedy it instead of going from one map to another in a linear fashion you go from one map to another then back to the first map but at a different time the story progress is still set on a strict path so when you really think about it the game is linear but with maps repeating themselves times which is brilliant if you look at it from the development side of things from the player s perspective it s not too bad considering you can leave a map at any time and load another to finish up a sidequest or grind some cp for levels as for the story you can hate it or love it but it s a separate matter if you can understand it having played through the game and done all the sidequests i still don t know if i understood it or not i didn t bother much with the dlc it seemed pointless you either play texas hold em as sazh in a casino or do some vs grinding with lightning the arena is nice if you want a real challenge i ll briefly mention what i liked about this game the music alright now that that s out of the way let s talk about the characters and dialogue i just can t stand that every other sentence these teenagers blabber out is supposed to sound deep and perhaps they can if you re high enough the topics the main characters dabble in are philosophy motivational poster quotes and moral high ground with your usual anime tropes as filler something about needing to protect certain individuals and defeat the level design there are some really weird and archaic design choices made all with the sole purpose of wasting your time i ll bring up some very specific examples like the entirety of augusta tower not fun not challenging very annoying the weather control device in archylte steppe there are weather modes that you can switch between by using levers you need to set the lever combination up or down for specific weather which then triggers a second unskippable cutscene and unless you re a speedrunner you will not have memorized the combinations so you try again hope for the best and look at the damn cutscene again why not simply give me a selection of the weather modes with the currently active one being a different colour it doesn t take me out of the game and most importantly it doesn t waste my time the slow giant rock critter ride in sunleth waterscape was okay the first couple of times but after the third time i despised it the escalators in academia the ones that go in the opposite direction so you either bunny hop through it or interact with a lever for a couple of seconds to switch directions just why last map has the tetris block barges you stand and wait on a platform ledge for the block to turn towards you you get on the block and wait for it to turn towards the next platform you move to that platform and you do it again and again and again the devs must ve really thought the environment visuals were simply too good not to force the player to enjoy them i think on this map you spend more time waiting than doing anything else and that includes the encounters and the best part about this map is that you get to redo it from the start if you want to gather all the fragments because of the bestiary character progression did you know that levelling commando on a big crystal gives bonus strength and levelling ravager on a big crystal gives bonus magic what about the fact that if you level synergist to an odd level e g from to on a big crystal you ll get bonus magic and the best one is of course levelling saboteur even level on big crystal gives bonus strength and odd gives bonus magic the maximum level for each role is so if you waste too many levels of the above roles on small crystals you ll make your characters much weaker than if you d meticulously followed the rules and you cannot reset the crystarium i personally didn t notice these rules being mentioned in the game so you d need to pay close attention to know monster breeder the unit on your side in a battle is a monster that you capture not that i mind the fact that you can breed monsters to become better than either of your main characters but you d need to do quite a bit of research and experimentation to know how what and when to fuse monsters together to get the best passive abilities aside from fusing monsters together the monsters have their own crystarium which is a bit different they use items instead of cp which means grinding for items here s an example of how to get one of the most powerful ravagers in the game a blue chocobo first you need to catch one and a blue chocobo is a rare pokemon so getting it to even spawn without the battlemania fragment skill can take some time next up you need to get lucky to actually catch it there s another fragment skill that can help with that but rng is rng because it s a ravager role you ll want to boost its magic which means leveling the crystarium with mostly mana type materials for levels i used potent materials the rest all mana you ll need to level it to at least which is good because getting mana crystals is a pain so much so that i stopped levelling the bird after level since it s asking for crystals per level and i can t be bothered anymore it didn t really matter i still beat the final boss in minutes instead of the target time of minutes got it levelled up to great now all you need to do is just capture other monsters a few of which are rare one of which only exist on a map and you ll need two of them so better save before battle and reload if capture fails then close the gate and redo some story parts to get the second one level up these monsters as well until specific abilities become available then infuse them in the correct order and you re done i understand why some people would enjoy this process not me though granted creating the most overpowered critter isn t required to beat the the good old japanese grind for because sometimes it s not the skill that matters but how much time you re willing to give obviously playing of a game is optional and i definitely would ve hated the game less if i had not decided to go for it but here we are it s mostly about fragments and you ll actually want quite a lot of them to unlock certain fragment skills i ll just mention a few good examples of the grind captain cryptic quiz in academia getting a question wrong will make him disappear and reappear in one of the possible locations so you ll need to search around this annoying map once you get all the questions correct you ll get a fragment and now you get to do it four more times i think nobody would find this fun but this is the way of the japanese grind the monster professor fragment which requires you to completely fill out the bestiary will require you to have finished the game and gotten most of the paradox endings to finally complete it needless to say it was the last one i completed what s so bad about filling the bestiary for example did you know that a cactuar enemy can use an ability to change into a giant cactuar during a fight in fact that s the only way to encounter a giant cactuar considering it takes a long time until it uses the ability you ll have beaten the cactuar way before it does it how would you know to wait for cactuar to morph into giant cactuar without looking it up on the internet i have no clue how would you know where to find the missing monsters actually nevermind how would you even know which monsters you re missing from your list without looking it up on the internet i have no clue once again i suppose you d just go map by map and try to spawn all the monsters until you thought you had them all ']

['warning this is a recommendation with a huge list of but s and things you need to know and is very much not a glowing one and first thing to know do not play this game with steam cloud on turn it off before you even start in the game library properties otherwise the game will crash very often during now loading screens and attemtps to switch to offline saves mid game will result in infinite wasted in final fantasy xiii properly and succeedes in many cases all rpg systems and mechanics are still flawed but are much more fun to play with battles are less boring and actually require some thought and the progressions is rather open the levels are no longer go from point a to point b in a corridor and while they re reused constantly with variations via the whole time traveling plot they re mostly fun and look good game has a system similar to oldschool random encounters which is both good and annoying there are horrible puzzle sections although they are ussually tied to optional areas and quests and there are few super annoying and boring platforming sections but the game is not too insane with those what is also good is that the plot is happening it s weird to put this storydriven rpg has plot as a plus but after ff xiii that has nothing happening for dozens of hours having things happen story expand characters develop all the time is great the story itself is like with ff xiii more interesting in theory than in execution and few twists and turns feel not just silly but completely undermining some of the other stuff but it has moments and is surprisingly darker than you might expect but overall storytelling and themes are good waaaay better than hours of nothing from ff xiii even if a lot of stuff feels stupid or absurd and tone can be off by a lot it looks good it sounds very good if sometimes unexpected soundtrack switches from usual ff to resident evil parasite eve feel same composer to devil may cry in seconds and always catches you off guard it has ['prosconsfirst let me tell you one thing i bought and went into this game expecting an exeptionally bad piece of software what i got exceeded my expectations by a long margin this game is believe it or not but first things first it is terrible just plain awful even if you thought the story of the first final fantasy xiii was fine and never left any questions unanswered story will most likely go over your head i have to admit it lost me very early on it makes sense in the end but then again not really don t try to wrap your head around it it s not even the fact that it is about time travel which in itself has always been one of the most confusing topics in movies and video games no it s just that the story writer went and took a rather simple concept and filled it with lots and lots of technobabbles and weird pseudo scientific assumptions to make it sound more complex than it actually is some of the dialogues in this game reminded me of what it feels like to watch an episode of star trek half the time they don t make any sense other times the characters just blurt out seemingly random thoughts and assertions which we are apparently supposed to take for granted more often than not they just make up the rules as they go along it starts with lines like to which to the answer is you ll hear the paradoxes did it bit a lot or how about this one from the casino just go with it there is only one real way to play this game in my opinion turn your brain off don t think too much about what s happening take in the atmosphere and relax whilst listening to the phenomenally good soundtrack which leads me to the next bullet point if you compare it directly to final fantasy xiii then this game is undoubtedly much more open every map has lots of secret and sometimes invisible stuff to discover in every corner and i personally just love the attention to detail everywhere like when your character s foot step noise dynamically changes depending on the surface he s walking on including small puddles on the pavement or when you use your weird moogle magic and every npc in the vicinity gathers around in curiousity the world generally feels alive and is really atmospheric my only gripe is the way they handled invisible level bounderies it is kind of immersion breaking when your characters can jump up towering trees that are dozens of meters high but at the same time the knee high rubble in another area proves to be an insurmountable obstacle and you need to find a way around it some of the aforementioned items you can find allow you to unlock more and more areas and side quests speaking of side quests though the area selection hub does in my opinion a poor job in distinguishing the main story line from side quests with how often i traveled back and forth between different time lines and areas i wasn t always quite sure if i was doing a mandatory or an optional quest and in some cases a quest is even optional in the beginning up until the game tells you that it is now mandatory for the story progression and you realize you already did all that hours ago oh well the missions itself feature a good variety of objectives nothing out of the ordinary but they usually require specific actions in specific locations and times to change something along the time line it never felt like i was doing boring chores now let s get to my favorite part of the game aside from walking around and talking to npcs the field gameplay features small puzzles every now and then most of them are insultingly easy though some of them are plain annoying now the battle system is largely the same as xiii s however it has one neat little addition you can now recruite pok mon to fight at your site i have to admit i m a sucker for the shin megami tensei series and its demon recruiting and fusion mechanic and final fantasy system is kind of similar to this whenever you kill a monster there is a chance to capture it you now have your very own lvl version of this monster with basic abilities which you can either keep leveling up with specific monster materials random drops loot can be bought later or you decide to infuse it in order to pass some of its abilities on to a stronger monster this way you can spend dozens of hours trying to create unique and powerful allies unfortunately as much as you can customize your monsters the same thing does not apply to your main characters their level progression is much more set in stone both of them have obvious roles they excell at like serah is a much better ravager than noel while noel is the better synergist and so on so you obviously want to focus on these first additionally the very high encounter rate lets you accumulate way too many cp exp too quickly leading to overleveled characters who steamroll every story boss in a matter of seconds both main characters even stopped learning new abilities about and were completely maxed out a little over halfway through the game speaking of encounters in this game they technically aren t random encounters as they appear on the map in front of you and you could theoretically avoid them this is easier said than done however as many of the ['i m going to revise this review i had initially given up on this game due to mysterious bugs that hampered my experience i can t say what the cause was but since it stopped i was able to get through the rest of the game i ll keep it short this game is gorgeous it came out back in and it holds up great the ost is fantastic as well and i d rank it among the best of the series gameplay wise it branches off from xiii a bit in terms of how it handles the crystarium and party composition it s a straightforward upgrade path but you can choose other roles and perks for the characters as you progress catching and outfitting monsters is cool but not having a party is a bummer boss battles are pretty fun in this game the combat events are a flashy and fun way to end a battle it s a nice additional touch they also seem faster than in the previous game or perhaps just shorter in general switching paradigms also doesn t pause the game like it used to so combat flows more smoothly the levels in this game are far more open which is somewhat refreshing there are times where you really don t feel like having to run to given locations though you do have access to chocobos to make travel a bit faster got a nice chuckle out of the red chocobo you ll know what i mean when you get one the story is a whole lot of nothing for most of the game due to of the game being a search for lightning expect a lot of wait what moments as things get confusing at times especially as you approach the end the game isn t exceptionally long if you don t do too much extra work so it largely doesn t overstay its welcome well sort of you will spend a significant amount of time upwards of minutes average waiting for the game to load when going to a time period sometimes entering battle can yield significantly long load times that can be grating especially if you re looking for particular things between areas or god forbid grinding for materials outside of that it s alright i got some hope out of it you will have to apply a mod or two for this game to be playable the majority of problems this game has and leviathan s tears fixes the rain textures note that you may still run into a strange bug or two game was doing funky things with my controller for quite some time if it works it s fine if not well you don t have many other options i don t think anything can be done about load times unfortunately i do like this game not more than the first one overall but it can be a fun time i like that square did try to set this one apart from xiii and it does have some cool ideas the openness is a nice contrast even if there are instances where you d rather just get to the point battles flow more smoothly and boss fights are mostly pretty fun the monster capture raising aspects add a bit of variety to party composition and some of them damn near trivialize the game so it s rewarding in a sense there s plenty of optional content to do if you re interested so you won t get bored anytime soon provided you were enjoying yourself to begin with the main problem is just the port it s a damn poor job if you are a patient man like myself you can manage to get through this if you haven t played final fantasy before i would recommend the version it runs more smoothly than this due to the variable performance i would not buy this at full price it s playable as your computer can probably brute force it at this point but it would benefit hugely from a fix patch for bucks it s fine it can be fun albeit kind of directionless ymmv i can t strongly recommend it but if it works it s worth trying ']

pretty bad b one of the biggest problems happens during cinematic cutscenes your game will try to load a lot of new information and also try to autosave which worked on the console however the longer you play the game the more information the game will tryto process i e completed ongoing quests certain events that need to be implemented and the biggest thing are savestates which will take a significant amount of processinging all occuring in the small amount of time oof moving between the world you are in and the world select whenever you transition between worlds which in mid to late game is a significant amout of times this game will try to load process and save all at the same time during the early game this problem isn t very apparent but at hrs the change becomes much more apparent eventually past hrs triggering even small cutscenes which automatically load and autosave at the same time will often crash the game causing whatever progress was made to all feel worthless ['let me preface this review by stating that i m a long time final fantasy fan yet i am not a jrpg fan that may sound confusing i am not a fan of i know some games are repeats in there depending on the japanese release i have played and i wish i had skipped over this one let me explain below graphics the graphical fidelity is no better than that said it s not an ugly game by any means i noticed my laptop which is not equipped for high end gaming tended to chug harder and burn hotter than when i played the pc port i found this strange since i noticed draw distance tended to be better on you ll also note the lack of monsters and their animations on the overworld map so why is this game more taxing presentation it s not any uglier than that s for sure but the characters are a lot flatter we didn t get to see much from serah in but in the actress seems a lot less interested and passionate at times the body language is overplayed and at other times there s no body language beyond standing arms akimbo setting i could ask what setting a lot of reviewers have said that you don t need to play in order to play this game that s true but you won t understand anything unless you read through all of the primers on the main screen even if you do the plot won t make much sense was enchanting because it introduced a novel theme that seemed unfamiliar a great purge of unclean civilians united six heroes who gain magical abilities to unite the citizens of a police state world to overthrow their god like leaders sounds nice right the setting of the sequel builds off of that but instead of introducing a unique or innovative story arch it starts from where left off our protagonist serah can t remember what happened how convenient and she has been separated from her sister and her lover a timelord deus ex machina character is introduced in the form of noel kreis lightning serah s sister summons him from another plane of time and reality to do her bidding the rest is in the plot development or lack there of but seriously time traveling my head already hurts characters noel is boring through the few hours i played he describes that he is from the future approximately years from the present plot point he explains that he has never known what a vegetable tastes like and that he is the last of man s existance so why does he look so clean and handsome and what is with his weird weapon nothing is explained noel s character design is meant to be ambiguous so we don t get too curious it s lazy and it s flat skip over this character serah is boring she acts like a scared little child when we re introduced to combat her feminization is peaked by giving her a bow and reducing her physical damage below what noel is capable of i m not promoting or dismissing any sort of female rights but i will point out that lightning was an exception to this feminization of damage rule in lightning was the female protagonist and she was more than capable of putting out tons of damage as well as taking tons of it in return she was by far one of the most powerful characters so why isn t serah kupo kupo kupo why did they add a moogle to this plot you will note that i avoided playing most of the games with a moogle in it well there s a moogle here he will plague your cutscenes and you will often find yourself hitting and skip the moogle only makes serah s sex more generalized any others i didn t get to i thought i might have picked up a new character after beating the hand in the second chapter but that was not the case i don t know what other characters exist out there but you will have to figure that out for yourself i won t touch this game again cutscenes as i stated in the graphics section the visual presentation is quite the same from that s a good thing most cutscenes look very nice one thing that upset me was the introduction of quick time events qte this requires you to make a movement or button press based on a notification on the screen from what i can tell the qtes don t actually affect anything in the plot sometimes you will notice your character painstakingly and stupidly getting squashed by a giant meteor only to roll over and get back up sometimes failing these qtes during a boss battle will result in extra damage likewise succeeding a qte might result in a status effect boost this doesn t belong in an rpg it ruined the balance and flow of the game and should not have been included gameplay the gameplay is very similar to but it feels like it behaves faster enemies seem to have less health and encountering enemies is much different you lack the techniques that you gain early on in and enemies aren t displayed on the overworld map instead enemies spawn randomly and they seem to spawn based on the number of steps you take after a certain number of steps enemies spawn and you have the choice of either running away or using the action button to swing your weapon and hit the enemy avatars if you connect before they do then you gain haste and surprise the enemy if you take too long or the enemy runs into your overworld avatars then you initiate combat as usual i initially thought this was kind of a cool idea a lot of rpgs have an initiative system however i quickly realized this was just a gimmick to reduce on screen rendering it also builds an unfair disadvantage for tactics by not showing what enemies you re up against all in all this was a failure by the creators leveling up has become a nightmare in order to create a simpler and more uniform character progression system the creators have done away with the traditional crystarium of and have created a new crystarium that allows you to choose which class you want to specialize in this character progression system feels a lot like the ff tactics games i get where the creators were coming from i am betting they received a lot of feedback from explaining why the individual crystarium stat point nodes were trivial of course you re going to level up for the least amount of cp there s no point in trying to use statistics and levels to negate that however the solution here was horrible basically every level in the crystarium is worth a certain point value regardless of what you invest it in serah and noel start with level in commando ravager and sentinel after you level up enough you can either gain a deeper specialization of these role trees or you can get an atb segment or a new role it is never explained who should specialize in what or how well rounded your party should be in each character had specialized roles and some characters synergized with others neatly i never got this feeling from give this game a i know it s rough but it simply did not capture my attention for more than a few hours it s not a bad game if you like jrpgs that are a bit over the top the fact that i enjoyed so much and yet i disliked this game really speaks volumes you don t have impressive antagonists like roche or the fal cie instead your villain is some emo kid with an ugly looking sword let me just reiterate that a lot of reviewers state that you don t need to play in order to play this game that s where they re wrong if you didn t play then you have no idea what these roles are the in game primers are brief and they don t at all explain how important these roles are i won t go into deeper specs of these roles so if you re interested please look up a game guide ']

['first and foremost buy this game for console instead you will recieve not only better more stable fps but you will also recieve better visual and audio quality final fantasy is the sequal to final fantasy xiii but it makes itself a whole different game while the battle system is the same as before it spruces it up with the ability to use monsters as companions this keeps battles fresh and gives you many options for paradigms i personally like this in combat but the cost of this is that you won t be gaining a third companion also the crystarium is different instead of multiple different trees to grow there is just one and what you gain per sphere depends on the role you choose to upgrade when you reach the end of the path your crystarium will expand then you are given multiple choices to level up including increasing atb and increasing the amount of accessories you can hold i like this change as well the two main characters are serah lightning s sister and noel a mysterious stranger from the future the premise is that after cocoon fell from the last game lightning vanished a few years later noel appears on a meteor and begins traveling through time with serah the story from there is driven by each point in time you travel to from what i ve played so far the cutscenes are mostly based on feelings instead of character development this means that most players will find that they don t care about serah and noel the story ends up being weak and unimmersive to add on the music is no longer orchestra but is now electronic j popish music if that s your style then godspeed but i personally perfered the orchestral tracks a few minor points are that now there are options to pick when you get in dialogue the side quests are more varied than just helping a l cie stone out and there are quicktime events in some cutscenes but the main thing i have to complain about it is the quality of the port it s terrible no matter what you do maybe unless you have a really good computer you will experience frame rates all over the place but almost never over also the audio quality ends up being terrible it sounds like the voice acters are speaking through a cheap headset instead of a studio microphone so to summarize pros revamped battle system pets crystarium revamp time travel makes the game less linear more varied side quest premises branching dialogue and quick time events make the game more engaging than it would ve been cons story and main characters are uninteresting and melodramatic the pc port is terrible so the bottom line is if you aren t a fan of ffxiii look up different better games if you are a ffxiii fan then this game may be worth your while if you buy it on console ']

['all in all it is a step up from the previous game it still has the paradigm system and technically less characters but that you only ever got to use three at a time anyway encountering enemies is at different times an unlocking the respective areas was actually fun the story is mostly a mess it starts off confusingly and remains largely detached from the previous game save for it s characters t really know anything about it the story had some neat concepts some enjoyable character developments occurred with some touching emotional pieces but it felt disjointed and separate a primary example is noel kreiss himself his character is somehow all over the place mysterious cause lack of content and boring all at the same time yet at some point you can identify with him with the new this is a poorly written story what goes in concert with that is some of the music choice much like my story comment some of the b team just randomly threw songs at this that just didn t fit while using some previous music which was tried and true and some well placed bangers it left me feeling confused but mostly cot content with the audio the default combat music was terrible though overall ['final fantasy is definitely an improvement over the first game but knowing how square enix is it s still riddled with technical issues mostly resulting from a bad port of the game as usual the game runs poorly capping in at no matter what the store page says about possibilities low bitrate audio crisp fmvs due to compression for some reason and the game only using of ram like the first game and of course the same author who compiled a bunch of fixes for the first game has also written a steam guide on how to enhance so go check it out as usual it contains performance fixes crash fixes and the modernization of the game although this time the hd textures are a lot more subtle than the first game there s also a mod that restores past dlcs that square enix removed due to licensing issues which is pretty nice the improvements come from the overall gameplay from redesigned drop tables and how the game calculates monster drops to tiny optimizations in the battle system the crystarium is also not as linear as it was in the first game but they went a bit overboard as it s almost impossible to understand how the thing works without looking up a guide and advancing through the crystarium willy nilly will result with you having a weaker party and may make the game quite more difficult than it should be in the late game traversing the game world isn t as linear as the first game as well unlike ffxiii where you just follow a predetermined path up until the third to the last chapter which goes back again to being linear a couple of chapters later offers players the freedom to explore any place they want at any time emphasis on which makes for a very modular non linear way of playing the game of course some places have higher levelled enemies than the others which would indirectly guide you back to where the game wants you to be but it isn t as spoon fed as the first game and if you persevere enough even places blocked by the sheer level of enemies are still doable the biggest change in my opinion is the introduction of it s basically like pokemon where you capture a monster that you fight and have it battle for you in instead of a human party member you will be utilizing the powers of monsters each monster specializing in their own role and one role only unlike in ffxiii where you can pretty much choose from any role at any time limits that by making your third party member be of limited roles you can only have up to three third roles that you can switch between gil is not a notable issue anymore in the game you still need a hefty amount of it when you re building your monsters but unlike the first game you can easily amass gil as you play through the story in my experience i had amassed over thousand gil just from clearing chapters and no items are ridiculously expensive in the shop which is really nice as well no more million gil material that you will only use once and you have to get another one way or another cp just like in the previous game can be acquired as you play the game and you almost don t need to grind for it or at least don t directly grind because capturing monsters isn t as simple as it seems and you will probably need to fight a lot of enemies to find really good monsters to add to your party which in turn will make you amass a lot of cp before you even realize it you can easily be underlevelled in this game but it s as easy to be overlevelled as well that s because the crystarium stages aren t locked behind story progression so if you have so much free time in your life and perseverance you can upgrade both characters crystarium to the latest stage even during the early game another thing that i liked about this game square removed the tedious way of levelling and upgrading weapons and accessories you can now just buy weapons to replace your current ones and the shop will even offer you the upgraded version of the weapons in exchange for gil and materials that are relatively easy to acquire compared to traps and dark matter which means pretty cheap too and most of them come from enemies that are relatively easy to kill compared to toises and long guis of course there s still materials that can only be acquired from rare spawning enemies and the material itself is a rare drop from said enemies but the game introduces a new feature called to help you with the grind one of the key objectives in the game is to collect fragments i won t be diving into what these are but if you collect enough of these you can talk to an npc that will give you depending on how far you are in the game and how many fragments you have collected so far these fragment skills range from little adjustments like being able to move the camera during cutscenes to insane game altering effects like making rare enemies to spawn more often or increase the amount of enemies that you can encounter each of this fragment skill has their own use and you can tweak them any time you want beating the game will also give you a fragment skill to see other endings that you normally couldn t get which adds more to the non linearity of the game i think this is what really separates from its predecessor ffxiii practically has no post game content once you beat the game it s pretty much the end of course you can fill out all the characters crystarium to their maximum level after beating the game but there s not much to it the ci eth stone missions that you have to do after beating the game is only that way because you are virtually limited by your characters stats that are locked behind the stage crystarium that can only be unlocked after beating the game but technically speaking you can do all ci eth stone missions even before the final boss thus technically making post game content non existent i really feel that ffxiii had a dlc that never came to be since all post game content is all about making your characters even stronger but that s a topic for another day in you get the alternate endings called after you beat the game and there are a handful of them to go through the game also has actual dlcs to play through after beating the game which i think ffxiii is really lacking like i mentioned earlier and it will take you hours to finish all of them the dlc even includes literally a coliseum where you can fight a bunch of enemies to test your skills and the monsters that you have built throughout the game unlike ffxiii where the only post game you can do are the ci eth stone missions that you can actually do before beating the game actually offers content that you can only do after beating it like i said i grinded for materials and monsters in the game so you can pretty much shave of to hours off of the recorded playtime in this review i am also writing this review before doing post game so expect the playtime hours to jump to i don t know i guess maybe to hours more i am still not finished building my monsters and i have yet to begin viewing the paradox endings let alone the dlcs and stuffs however as much as i like this game and being the cheapskate that i am i still recommend buying this game on sale it s a pretty old game especially if you count the years from its initial release on the and spending almost bucks to play it with technical issues that square could have easily fixed but didn t isn t really worth it but i really recommend playing this game especially if you liked the first game ']

['bad port of a pretty very good jrpg depending on your tastes and what you find appealing you ll probably at least get console level performance at higher and arbitrary resolutions if you cap to uncapped you ll likely get severe fps drops when loading new areas of maps and might experience generally lower fps in crowded parts of the game too you will really want to use the mod as well as the or large address aware patches check pcgw despite all this i more or less the game nowhere was ever unplayably bad and my cpu isn t too great compared to stuff from the last year or so that i hear gets a fair improvement in performance i will say on the whole performance is substantially worse than xiii though with regard to the game itself it s a zany time travelling adventure with a veritable bevy of side content in the form of minigames collectibles extra unlockable abilities and game modifiers more money encounters alternative hidden endings etc a really cool villain with a big sword and some great dlc boss fights albeit gated effectively behind near completion due to how difficult some of them are graphics very nice for a console title from early character models look great environmental art is stunning at times as it was in the original with some locations being visually striking and extremely imaginative some lower res textures here and there there are a handful of graphical mods also available monster designs are frequently reused from and continue to look great music and sound just great all around very large diversity in genres some really top tier jrpg boss themes voice acting is solid in both english and japanese but the voice volume is a little low in some cutscenes there are mods that address this gameplay the core battle system is basically refined from the original you have two party members you can swap control of freely versus the original at a time while the third party member you can assign from a pool of monsters you can recruit monster recruitment is its own sub system including leveling paths learning skills and transferring skills to new monsters to make super powerful party members the atb system works basically the same as in except the usage feels snappier and more fluid with much less of a delay on paradigm changes the combat system is really exceptional and makes me sad that it will probably never return in future ff entries i d recommend checking out at overview of the system but at its strongest it can feel exceptionally dynamic and reactive with you having to constantly learn enemy attack patterns and how to respond on the fly given what monsters you have how much damage you need to deal in a fixed time etc really good stuff the other big facet of gameplay is exploration which is far less linear than almost to a fault it can often feel overwhelming with how many possible areas you can explore at any given time leading to hidden enemies bosses sidequests all these things also reward you with additional story scenes some more context into what life is like after the end of and datalog entries which really flesh out characters and lore more exploration will also reveal minigames including races poker slot machines etc included dlc secret episodes superbosses it feels like the game is more side content than main game so if that is something you really like in your jrpg you ll probably dig it here story and characters the story is needlessly convoluted and retcons the ending to a game which ending more or less conclusively shortly after ending everyone becomes convinced that lightning disappeared and then time travel shenanigans start to happen and lightning s sister serah and a time traveler called noel team up to solve these problems the balance is probably the opposite to which had arguably dislikable characters situated in a world and mythos that were extremely interesting in the story is held up by character interactions and a villain who is really compelling despite a story that sort of starts and ends in the same place overall probably a story mixed in with characters exploration battle system music visual design a really nice experience for fans of just be aware of the port issues and how to mitigate them ']

['it s definitely a fairly unstable game with a number of issues that cause graphical lag and random crashes some of which even cause steam to freeze and crash as well the community patches help a little bit installed after hours of dealing with many crashes but is far from a proper fix it s unfortunately not just an issue of people not having good enough pc s either i played the game at with shadow resolution and dlss with a window open monitoring resource usage i found that gpu usage and memory both usually sat around usage and bouncing around a bit of course with cpu never going above memory around i actually found that switching to dlss actually caused more issues while gpu usage topped at around the game significantly dropped to a laggy frame rate and i also had issues with audio falling out of sync and clipping out as well interestingly enough anyways enough of that and to the actual game so we get hit away with the same combat system as ff which is perfectly fine given that it is a sequel and whatnot the keyboard controls weren t exactly conveniently mapped so using a controller is much more pleasant however i did find that this game suffered from the same issue that ff also had which is that i can more or less beat every battle minus a handful of boss battles by just defaulting to relentless assault com rav occassionally switching to diversity com rav med for harder fights in all the older ff games i can t really think of any where this really happens and to me it just takes out a piece of fun of the game even ff which had a similar combat system didn t really seem this obscenely easy i honestly found myself just spam clicking a on the controller while browsing my phone in the midst of most of the battles i got into just zero attention required and still found myself getting star ratings most of the time i almost wonder if the game would be better off without auto battle just to promote more interactivity another minor annoyance i found at higher levels is your spell list is a two column list that can t fit all the spells for a class at once on it mainly for rav i wish they expanded that to be a column or expand more on the screen just so i could see everything i had available at once since it s an active combat system in turn based combat of older ff games that wasn t really required since you had all the time in the world to decide what to do i also found myself annoyed with the insane reuse and retexturing of all assets i absolutely expected it to some extent of course but jeez it feels like a bit much one map was used over with different lighting and a few others used over the steppe at least was managable for it s credit and i did love academia for the most part but i really expected at least a few models for weapons at the very least for the chaos weapons but no just another recolor on top of the base model not even an interesting texture applied to it also i ll note i haven t played ff lightning returns yet either overall i wanted to enjoy the game but between the bugs inconsistencies cliches over reuse and the blandness of battle i just honestly spent a fair bit of the time playing wishing i was onto the next piece of the story already so i could finish it ']

['tl dr no recommendation due to technical aspects of the port wrapper but yes if you re willing to troubleshoot high probability of crashing as purchased the content and artistry of the game itself is a thumbs up unfortunately it s wrapped in a technical package that is prone to crashing without taking measures on your end to attempt to stabilize the game while it runs for my part i m using a so called patch for those who don t know it s not that the patch is gigabytes in size it s to allow the game to use more than the original memory limit imposed by hardware constraints when this game was originally developed the patch itself is a few kilobytes i also had to disable cloud save due to crashing hanging related to saving the game in my case the game would crash at points where it would normally save and the save process completed because i could reload the game and it would resume right where it crashed so i think it s some kind of interaction between the game and steam around save data that s causing the problem i can t in good faith recommend this game as it doesn t work as expected out of the box so to speak i want to recommend this game because i just replayed through ffxiii on steam no less without having to do anything special and just the opening sequence of this game reveals that the team who worked on the content side of took a lot of lessons from the first game and tried to evolve with this work i do recommend this game to those who are willing to do some troubleshooting to enjoy an otherwise worthwhile game ']

['this game is some sort of weird mixture of pokemon final fantasy doctor who and an old school collectathon your third party members are three of a pretty large array of enemies you capture randomly throughout the game the gameplay is a lot like ffxiii and the battle system will feel very familiar to you if you ve played it this time around instead of having a separate crystarium for each job class there s just a single crystarium for all roles which gives you a chance to slightly customize your characters if you re into max min character development the real depth comes from the monsters you collect they each have their own crystariums traits and skills they can learn the monster crystarium is more similar to the sphere grid from ffx where you can use a part to level the monster up and choose which stat you want to raise to make it more fun you can also infuse your monster with other monsters that will allow it to gain spells and traits from the monster that s consumed all in all there s a lot of depth there if you want to dig deep but it s not necessary if you just want to play through the game the story is there it s time travel nonsense and it gets in it s own way more often than not noel is difficult to like and serah is just missing something these are your only two party members to make the characters engaging you get plenty of cameos if you re into that sort of thing but overall i couldn t really tell you too much of what happened because time travel is annoying outside of your standard ff affair there s fragments to collect throughout the game this is banjo kazooie style each area has x amount of fragments that you may or may not get a clue to find it was a cool idea to see implemented in an rpg but it lacks the charm of what makes those old collectathons fun to do and you ll be a little sick of it once you get in the also paradox endings that you can unlock using some late game items that are somewhat interesting this game is pretty easy to get achievements on i only had issue with slot machines and it took several hours of rubber banding my controller to unlock that one there s also a super annoying quiz section that refuses to die in one area that you need to get through otherwise it s not too hard to this is a lazy port you ll more than likely need to check the community guides to patch the game to make it work somewhat decent even then you get a lot of flickering and framerate issues but nothing game breaking and nothing that ruined my enjoyment of the game the game crashed once and in a very inopportune sport but that was the only real issue i had with this port also there s an area where people just fall over for no reason it was really captivating ']

['edited to add i see that by far the most common complaint other reviewers have is instability or other issues with the port all i can say is that i never experienced any of these problems and usually if there s technical issues that some people have and others don t i get them really bad i had an absolute nightmare with divinity original sin for example the only technical issue i had with this game was occasional slowdowns that were fixed easily by turning off cloud saves i can t promise you won t have those problems but i can tell you they re not happening to everyone by any stretch of the imagination original review it s the same basic engine as ffxiii but the gameplay experience is everything that game wasn t exploration oriented and radically non linear and fairly lighthearted despite the sometimes apocalyptic plot this makes for a much more enjoyable gameplay experience than the dour linear and overly hand holding ffxiii i d go so far as to call it the only direct sequel to a final fantasy game that is actually better than the game it s a sequel to it s a bit simplified from its predecessor though this is compensated somewhat by giving you access to almost all of the gameplay mechanics right from the beginning the original final fantasy xiii eventually gave you a bit more to work with but it took two thirds of the bloody game to get there thus the common complaint that most of the game feels like a tutorial the previous game s weapon upgrades are particularly missed although working out which monsters to use in your third slot is at least as interesting the characters are a bit flat and while the plot sometimes uses its time travel aspects in interesting ways i suggest not trying too hard to work out how time travel works here because ultimately it s pretty incoherent my biggest complaint though is that the challenge level is very low even by final fantasy standards slower advancement through the crystarium and giving out some abilities at much higher levels would have helped the pacing some may view this as a positive as it does make the game very newcomer friendly naturally it s gorgeous with a great soundtrack it is a relatively modern final fantasy after all and that alone would make it more enjoyable than not if i can t give an unqualified recommendation there s nevertheless a lot more to like here than not ']

['such mixed feelings with this game in short a sizable amount of people really hated xiii so they ran in the opposite direction in almost every regard personally i thought xiii was kinda of ok i the jumping around from time to time while trying to make a better future structure of the game it makes locations worth revisiting and it s interesting to see the changes i even enjoy the crystal fragment collecathon thing they have going on i like the extra bosses and the completely optional locales that do nothing but flesh out the world and the characters there is a lot of interesting things that are actively hidden in this game having said all that it s bizarre to think about how years ago chrono trigger did this way better but is still really enjoyable in its own right my main problem with is pretty much the same as it was with xiii the story is complete garbage it s just complete garbage in a different way xiii suffered from an incomprehensible plot obscured by terms that weren t explained until of the game and a party that had no idea what it actually wanted to do until the last hour of gameplay meanwhile suffers from having an atrocious plot that is explained excessively at every corner no one misses a chance to spout exposition but they mostly just say words that make no sense in context or otherwise the game is loaded with some of the biggest plot holes ['i have been a long time fan of the final fantasy series as such i ve had some standards that i look for in all final fantasy games ffx was my favorite with a great storyline that didn t make me feel above things which is amazing combat is again random with load screens for each battle escaping is difficult and getting premeptive strikes impossible on a decent number of enemies like ffxiii it s auto battle until they die unless you need healing the story line seems like it was built to give clarity as you go on but it just seems like one big convulted mess one thing i always loved was mini games as they provided a quick distraction now those mini games are mandatory and timed so the fun is replaced by forced challenge at least in previous games you had they opprotunity to study as you went letting everyone enjoy at their own pace not to mention sidequests which only indicate the original quest giver on the map not the target this would be fine in a game that offered decent options ['final fantasy is the direct sequel to the hot garbage known as final fantasy xiii i would have never guessed that i would have had so much fun with after my soul draining experience with ffxiii it is no exaggeration that square enix took fan feedback from the first game close to their hearts and did a thorough a with this game in fact square enix made such drastic measures that they retconned the ending of ffxiii and pretty much wrote away most of the l cie fal cie and focus jargon this is one of the few games i ve played where the sequel is so much better than its predecessor that you could just pretend that the first game never existed another game series that comes to mind is mass effect and mass effect story takes place directly after ffxiii and changes the ending instead of lightning reuniting with her sister serah lightning is literally erased from history and everyone believes that she sacrificed herself along with vanille and fang to save the inhabitants of cocoon the only person that seems to remember what truly happened is serah the cause of all this is caius a man in a purple jumpsuit and wields a cool looking sword eye weapon who has manipulated time itself for some nefarious purpose it is up to serah and noel a mysterious time traveler from the future to fix the time paradoxes and confront caius as a time travel story the game completely misses the mark and tries to explain mysterious things because of time magic fortunately at least what story has going for it is that it is at least mildly comprehensible with no need to consult the datalog there are also nice episodic recaps everytime you load your save in the first hour of gameplay you can tell square enix immediately did right with this game characters no longer spout non sequiturs at each other there are multiple branching paths to explore you can actually talk and have conversations with npcs and finally you can access most of the gameplay immediately with the rest unlocking within the first three hours the paradigm system from ffxiii also got a revamp serah and noel will always be in your party with a rotating slot used for monsters that s right is also a pok mon esk monster collecting game each monster represents a specific crystarium role and it becomes a quest in itself to find and raise the best commandos ravagers medics etc that said if you didn t enjoy the paradigm system in the first game this game will not be changing your mind i was not a fan of some of the other changes that square enix has made for some reason they learned that that qtes are pretty popular with the kids these days and included them throughout the game the qtes show up in cutscenes and during battle hitting every qte will deal bonus damage or reward you with a special prize fortunately failing the qtes isn t an automatic fail another feature included is branching dialog sequences while branching dialog is much appreciated as it helps flesh out serah and noel it usually only rewards an item if you pick the one correct serious choice there are also severe pacing issues with first episodes are fairly easy and straightforward to follow the episode is gated off until serah and noel collect specific fragments located in various timelines the game give you hints in which timelines and areas to find these fragments but the problem is the game does not tell you how in order to reach these specific timelines you need to have enough wild artefacts the keys to opening these timelines the game never keeps track of which locations have wild artefacts are in them and it becomes painfully annoying to scour through each and every timeline for them the problem is also exacerbated when these wild artefacts are impossible to access without pursuing some relatively long quest lines unless if by dumb luck you opened the right timelines and did the right quests i strongly recommend resorting to a guide if you get stuck at this suffers from a low production value and most of the content is recycled from the original game the new music is eclectic and random and doesn t quite feel like a final fantasy soundtrack there are some catchy tracks like the red chocobo song but also random ones like this heavy metal song they put in some boss fights most of the character models and monsters are recycled from the original voice acting with the exception of the main cast is shotty with mog being the most annoying to listen to lip syncing is poorly done and you can notice characters moving their lips but not matching what they re saying the poor production values also creep their way onto the pc port of the game on windows the game will crash within the first few minutes of gameplay due to a memory issue the framerate advertised to run up to fps regularly dips down to fps even on powerful rigs i experienced no issues playing ffxiii on pc so it s strange how all of these bugs happen with the sequel luckily there is a great ff fan community that has provided most of the fixes to these issues see it is a shame that square enix did not patch their game even though it has been released almost years ago and counting final fantasy feels like a game that took major risks and paid off rather than living in the shadow of the first game and playing it safe square enix decided to take the series into a whole new direction with this sequel the game oozes with new ideas some brilliant and some awful this is a game that is so different from its predecessor that saying it is the sequel to final fantasy xiii is an insult yes it is using the same main characters and battle system but it does so much more than the original despite my complaints i enjoyed my time playing final fantasy look forward to playing the end of the trilogy lightning returns ']

['probably my favorite ff game to date so being an a continuation of you need to have played that game or know the events that happened in it to even grasp what is even happening in this game but i m got to say that this game did many more things right than wrong and truly showed that critique was heard loud and clear from the previous game before reading the nitpicks i highly recommend giving this game a go the good unique battle system that incorporates monsters that you can capture like but way better and you learn as you go and it encourages experimentation an amazing and diverse soundtrack honestly a big reason why i keep coming back to the series you can revisit areas you ve seen before unlike is quite good and highly recommend getting for the hardcore endgame fights and sazh the game feels big and there can be a lot to explore and nice rewards for doing so it is no longer game over if your party leader dies the meh ff is know to have some complicated puzzles and this edition is no exception as you will be running into them a lot and some can be quite rewarding to figure out but if you can t there are puzzle solvers online to help while i absolutely love the monster system one aspect that beats it in is customizing their abilities outside their skilltree can be a pain serah is not the most endearing character but she has her moments the yikes while not necessary to beat the game in anyway there is a collectible for completing all the maps which is really tough in some places so good luck ']

['final fantasy carries on where the previous title left off with serah searching for her sister this title overall is far less difficult than its predecessor less linear and also a little more open ended if you played ffxiii you ll be familiar with the paradigm combat system in this title you create up to three sets or packs of paradigms for use in different situations however instead of humans your party will consist of serah noel and a tamed beast which fulfills a fixed role you capture these beasts by defeating them in battle each has a set capture chance sound vaguely familiar yes this is somewhat like pokemon once captured each of your monsters will have a crystarium of their own instead of using traditional cp as you re used to and will do for serah and noel for the monsters you ll spend resources you acquire as drops through battles to level them up you can also infuse them with skills and passive attributes from other monsters you ve captured to make them even stronger your creativity is the limit in what types of paradigm packs you create the way in which the story is managed through the historia crux is unique this central hub allows you to traverse time as you so chose providing quick access to all the gates you have opened to specific locations from here you can also close a gate and roll back the story to where you were before you arrived at the gate you just closed you can then replay everything up to this point all over again while still maintaining your stats and cast of monsters if at any point you want to revert to your original forward progress return to the historia crux and just open the closed gate all will be restored again with no impact on your team it s a really cool system in my opinion there are still various weapons and accessories for your characters to employ but the demands on grinding out gil or special resources read trapezohedrons to get the best gear are gone the best weapons are acquired through more reasonable methods also it s worth reiterating this game is much more forgiving in combat than ffxiii as there are no hard caps on stats based on your degree of progress in the story if there is a minor drawback it s the graphics the pre recorded cinematics are not at all up to the level of ffxiii which was like watching a film at times but for the era this game was released in the visuals are still good framerates can be a little shaky especially while moving around towns or other areas but combat is pretty fluid overall considering the rest of the package this issue is not too difficult to overlook i ve played this title off and on since and still find it enjoyable more friendly to franchise newcomers than']

['continues the story of ffxiii seconds after it ended the timeline is changed by some tiny details but the consequences are huge this time around you don t run from scene to scene in one long story hose but you can travel through time and space from some sort of hub world every place in this game has at least one extra time you can travel to say you re in year of some place but a rock blocks your path so you travel to year and prevent the rock from being there in the first place you also don t have to do everything in a specific order and you can progress several threads of the story at the same time the combat system is quite unusual although upon further inspection it really is an amalgam of the usual ff atb active time battle a half real time half turn based system and role system mixed with some ffxii style ai what to do when the system expanded a bit since you can now pick your team leader since there are only two playable characters you ll have to catch level and breed monsters as a third player monsters can have only one role but you can have three monsters in the third slot to toggle through at the same time if your main is killed the game switches to the other character automatically so this time around a healing role as non main actually makes sense the roles can be fine tuned this time the level system has also been changed it looks simpler but you actually got more choice than in ffxiii they also added some sort of qte system in film sequences you re presented with a choice of buttons and different effects use magic or use melee you can then decide what to do or do nothing those choices usually have minor consequences but they always change something as usual for an ff game the game itself isn t very hard but there is a grind intensive endgame if you really want to do everything the pc port of this not without problems most of them are the same as in ffxiii aggressive vsync goes down to if cannot be held for a very short time this produced an annoying fps lag on my machine i had to limit the fps to with an external tool framerates other than will do weird things to the engine the general performance is wonky at best i think it s still better than the version because here you have a chance at playing the game in a high resolution with some aa at fps while the version struggled to maintain its fps at the internal resolution the game constantly polls usb hid devices for controllers if you have no controller connected you ll probably get a nasty stuttering effect there are workarounds but a controller is suggested the game plays well with two or six sound channels anything but or is likely to warp your audio channels around cloud saving crashes the game for some people i recommend turning it off because there is no actual map of which points break the game there is a slim chance of a game breaking bug in the first five minutes of the game without spoiling too much you ll see your character leave the battle screen but the game won t end the battle in this case restart the game and skip the scenes once you ve seen the first score card you ll know you re fine ']

['to me it s unfortunate that the string of final fantasy games that were released with the main number of xiii are written off as lousy games yes they all have flaws but that doesn t mean you can t enjoy playing them ff is a prime example of such a game when you release a sequel the game will inevitably be compared to the source material and i ll do such a thing here as well while i personally enjoyed xiii it has received its fair share of critizism the complaints were mainly aimed at the long tutorial sequence the linear gameplay and the convoluted story it also had some other issues such as a long transition time between the first paradigm shift the battle system in these games and the sometimes uninteresting or downright annoying characters square seemed to have done something about most complaints with the sequel for starters the opening level playing as lightning the protagonist of the first game is pretty interesting and while the tutorial sequence with serah lightning s little sister is a bit tedious again it doesn t drag on for hours to come besides that there are many ways to explore and revisit different regions and they give the player more options to choose from and more routes to follow this is probably the biggest change compared to its predecessor and it really helps the game i myself embrace most of the changes they made compared to the first game like i said i enjoyed xiii but most annoyances i had with the first game are removed for instance it took me about hours to finish xiii and a few sidequests but it took me another hours to wrap up every achievement in the game including having to grind the toughest enemy of the game in the hope of getting an item i needed for every weapon available it s way less tedious to complete everything in with the chocobo rider and slot machine achievements being the exceptions most battles are now avoidable which is also a step up from xiii they also improved and simplified the leveling system sped up the first paradigm shift and gave us the opportunity to use monsters as part of the team another feature they added in this game is the possibility of alternate endings while some can be found and viewed during your regular playthrough most can only be seen after beating the final boss that also brings us to the post game content there are many fragments in each world that serve as a sorts of collectibles some serve a purpose for instance opening a portal to a new and unexplored world or timezone some are easier to find than others the alternative endings you view also net you a fragment for that region with the time map you use to explore the worlds it s easy to see if you have found every fragment in that world and time zone what s even more interesting is that you have the power to rewind a certain section of the game meaning you can go back and play that part of the story as if you had never set foot on the world before this serves as a fun way to kill time and make sure you have explored every nook and cranny of the game the biggest drawback of xiii is the story while xiii s story was convoluted and complicated if you didn t take the time to read tons of story related content in your menu story is just too simple every problem in the world has to do with time paradoxes and time travel which is a key part of the gameplay as well and they can all be resolved by fixing said paradoxes that s as straightforward as it can get the game has a really interesting enemy in the form of caius ballad though he s mainly made interesting by some stellar voice acting by liam o brien the fights with him are especially very epic and the first battle with caius proves a hefty challenge if you don t level up some more it s too bad he didn t get as much screen time he deserved that being said the game is still very much enjoyable if you can look past the obvious plotholes or timeholes if you will badun tss will give you a fun time exploring the wonderful world of pulse in an abundance of time zones the music the graphics and especially the gameplay make for a game i wouldn t mind completing over and over i hope you ll give it a chance and enjoy it as much as i did ']
